results.description:
Here is a typical agenda of Art of Speaking Toastmasters Club's meeting.


• The Sgt at Arms calls for meeting to begin

• President of the club welcomes members and guests.  Invites the Toastmaster of the day to facilitate the meeting

• Toastmaster of the Day (TMOD) introduces other duty holders.


• TMOD invites speakers who have scheduled to speak that day. Members take turns to complete their projects under the Competent Communication manual or from one of the advanced manuals. Members & Guests offer feedback to the speakers. They also fill out ballots to select best speaker.


• After the prepared speeches segment is complete, Impromptu speeches (Table Topics) segment begins. All Guests are invited to participate. The goal is to think on your feet and speak for 1 to 2 minutes. Guests & Members fill out ballots to select best Table Topics contestant.


• Short Break to enable socializing & networking.


• Meeting reconvenes. General Evaluator takes charge of the meeting. Invites Evaluators to present their feedback on the prepared speeches. Guests & Members fill out ballots to select best evaluator.


• General Evaluators returns the control of the meeting back to the President of the club.


• President gives away awards to the best speaker, best Table Topics contestant and best Evaluator.


• Meeting comes to an end approximately between 12.15 pm and 12.30 pm.
results.how_to_find_us: North Edison Public Library
results.name: Art of Speaking Toastmasters Club Meeting

results.description:
“True yoga practice is a balance between strength and flexibility.Baddha Konasana Teaching a creative sequencing that allows balance into student’s life, is our goal. ”

– Nicole, Lead Instructor In our Balance Yoga Training we guide You through all different styles of yoga like Vinyasa Yoga, Iyengar Yoga, Ashtanga Yoga and Gentle/Restorative Yoga so end of the training you can mix it up and all incorporated into your classes. You will also learn abouth the history, theory and philosophy of yoga and what are the benefits of yoga asanas, breath, and meditation. We offer support every step of the way as you bulid your confidence to teach. Our program encourages each trainee to develop his or her own voice as an instructor.

Create smart, safe (injury free) and thoughtful sequencing what will make your class noticable and loveable.Upon completion of this training, we will teach you how to incorporate a flow into your class while you guide them to correct alignment. We believe building a strong foundation is a key to have a strong and injury free yoga practice.

results.description:
After all the rain this week, Saturday is forecast to be dry.  Dress in layers as it will be chilly in the morning.  This Nordic Walk is a shorter route than the Athletic class, it travels 2.75 miles and loops around the reservoir.  Walking time is approximately 50 minutes and 5500 steps! It is a beginner level. The 11:30 class is more athletic.
We supply the Nordic Walking poles and wireless  music.  Just bring a pair of headphones.  Please leave handbags at home...backpacks and belt bags are fine.  $10.00 exact change will be helpful.

If you need to cancel, we would appreciate you do so no later than Friday night - as we are bringing equipment for you.

For more details, view www.HYVAnordicwalking.com

Sonja/Bill

results.description:
</a>Let's welcome spring by experiencing the hubbub of Midtown Manhattan, then escaping to the quiet sanctuary of Roosevelt Island, a narrow strip of land in the East River, before making a few more miles (with some stops for Greek and Middle-Eastern food) in Astoria, Queens, one of the trendiest nabes in NYC.

https://www.eventbrite.com/custombutton?eid=22432916457

Starting at Penn Station, we'll pass Herald Square, the Empire State Building, and Grand Central Station, take the Tramway to Roosevelt Island, visit the new Four Freedoms Park (FDR), circle north on the Island to the Lighthouse and Octagon, then cross the Roosevelt Island bridge on foot to Queens for the outdoor Socrates Sculpture Park, Greek revival era mansions, Astoria Park, Hell Gate Bridge, and downtown Astoria. We'll wrap up, socialize, and celebrate at the Czech Bohemian Beer Garden for the end of walk gathering, just a block from the Astoria Blvd. (N,Q) stop for easy access back to 34th Herald Square - Penn Station.

Total mileage estimated at 12 miles.

<a href="http://api.ning.com/files/iwhKaf*i-h3o4qmK0Ingm*uImuWFo0km3Y9PkugjIIP6EiVoNHspvzGLaYuCLVK8X-B5jbbmfYBw8OXqgtzkMetLWpRf2VyW/RooseveltIslandandAstoriaWalk.pdf">Current Map & Directions (Revised 4/1/16)

The Soho, Little Italy and Chinatown walking tour will give guests an insider view of three popular neighborhoods.

The Soho, Little Italy and Chinatown tour takes guests walking tour through the iconic streets of Soho with its cast iron buildings and upscale designer shops.  Little Italy will smell the authentic Italian cooking and famous mafia locations.  Chinatown offers colorful vendors and shows.

Sat, April 2

Time: 10 a.m.

Price:  $35


http://www.ticketweb.com/t3/sale/SaleEventDetail?dispatch=loadSelectionData&eventId=6513995&REFID=rjmeetups

We will snack at the dumpling shop (cost of dumpling is $1 and this fee is not included in the tour)

Tour highlights include the experiences listed below -- Soho’s Sites Cast Iron District, Haughwout Building, Heath Ledger’s Apartment building, Oldest Cheese Shop in NYC, Lombardi’s Pizza – NY’s first pizzeria, Mafia Hangouts, Canal and Motts Streets

 NOTE: PRICE DOES NOT INCLUDE METRO CARD OR SAMPLINGS ON THE WALKING TOUR

results.description:
Private reading of selected discourses (suttas) from the Middle Length Discourses (Majjhima Nikāya) followed by group discussion and analysis led by Bhante Suddhāso.

About Bhante Suddhāso

An American Theravāda monk, Suddhāso Bhikkhu (Bhante Suddhāso) has studied under the guidance of some of the most important names in Western Buddhism like Ajahn Pasanno, Ajahn Amaro, Ajahn Vīradhammo, and Bhante Gunaratana. Ordained at Abhayagiri Buddhist Monastery in California, he was rst trained in the Thai Forest Tradition, then moved on to live at various Sri-Lankan monasteries in both rural and urban environments. A dedicated teacher, Suddhāso has taught to people of all different ages and walks of life, as well as college students of universities like Harvard, University of Mary Washington, and Suffolk County Community College.
results.name: MANHATTAN: 10AM Sutta Study with Bhante Suddhāso

results.description:
Meetup/Hangout – 9:45 am

Whole Foods (Union Square) -- upstairs cafe. Show up a bit early to say hi, chat, and drop off any thing you don’t want to run with: jackets, bags, phones, etc. Somebody will always stay to watch the stuff.

Run – 10:00 am

Run 1 mile, 3 miles, 5 miles, or whatever you want. We'll head to the West Side Highway together. No pressure and no limits. Totally informal. Lots of different paces for lots of different people. Even walking speed is encouraged!

Brunch – 10:45 am

Whole Foods has ALL THE FOOD. Come get some.

What to expect: a seriously fun group of runners who definitely do not take running too seriously . We will meet, chat, RUN, stretch, chat, EAT BREAKFAST and then leave. It’s that easy. First we run, then we eat!

results.description:
Special Dance Walk this Saturday, April 2, in honor of family & friends effected by Breast Cancer! Free. Bring your own ipod & earbuds--everybody listens to their own music as we dance walk around the park loop. What is "dance walking"? It's an improvised form of walking, with music, doing whatever movement comes naturally. It's walking and moving your arms. Or skipping, skitching, low-stepping, sideways running. It's responding to the rhythm, attitude, or story of the music you're hearing. In short, it's having a dance party in your living room, while walking through the park--hilarious and exhilarating. Check out this funny and smart article recently published about the Dance Walk in Prospect Park:

http://themomtropolis.com/dance-walk-you-know-you-want-to/
results.how_to_find_us: Standing in Grand Army Plaza farmer's market, walk 50 paces up toward the park on the park drive. We meet on the grassy triangle, just shy of the park loop.
results.name: Breast Cancer support Dance Walk this week!

http://www.vickielewis.com/photography-workshops/what_is_aperture/

Now you can understand what the most important settings on your camera mean in just one online class.
The three most important settings on your camera are f/stop, shutter speed and ISO. In this class, you'll learn, in very very simple terms, how your camera works, what each of these settings mean and how they impact your photographs.
After this class, you will feel more comfortable shooting in Shutter Priority or Aperture Priority. You'll have the 'basics' down to understand how to shoot on manual.
Sign up by March 28th, just $12.95. After March 28th, $19.95.
To sign up, go to: http://www.vickielewis.com/photography-workshops/what_is_aperture/ ￼
"Vickie is a sensational teacher, as well as photographer. I bought a camera, but only knew how to use it on automatic. She has given me a great start towards learning about manual. I would absolutely take another class with her. Carolyn"
“Great and informative”
“Thank you Vickie for organizing todays class. It was great and informative. I really enjoyed it and look forward for the next one!! ” –participant
You will learn:
• What is an f/stop or aperture?
• What is a shutter speed?
• What is ISO?

This class is suitable for beginners as well as those who have been shooting for awhile but want to develop a deeper understanding of how their camera works.
￼

Don’t miss out on Career Groundbreakers Conference for your chance to get ahead. Making connections with real people behind the brands and industries you love is the first step in making yourself stand out over other candidates.

results.description:
Dear friends,

Welcome in little Italy... in the Bronx!!

Atmosphere of the past, what local residents call the "real" Little Italy in New York.
Take a trip to rediscover ancient flavors while food industry experts show and explain the craftsmanship behind their products.
We will meet and start 'at "Gino's Pastry", which is famous for its monumental cakes. You will eat pastries where famous regulars like Joe Pesci, Al Pacino, and Ray Romano like to go.
We'll continue on to one of the best pasta shops in New York "Borgatti." They've been a legend in the Bronx for years. There they will explain the progress of making fresh pasta.
After that, we will make a brief stop at the church of "Our Lady of Mount Carmel." Where they still have mass in Italian.

The tour will continue to the bakery Addeo, another historical place in the Bronx.

You will hear about how they make their bread, and see their machines making their bread.
Then we'll move into the cornerstone of Little Italy: The Arthur Avenue Market. At the entrance of the market you can make a quick stop at "La Casa Grande Cigar," and admire the workmanship of their cigars.
In the middle of the market you'll find "Pete's Meat Market," They've been named the best butcher in New York City. There you will hear his story, and about his work with meat processing.

Last but not least, while in the market, we will stop at Mike's Deli, where chef David Greco, famous for beating Bobby Flay on the food network, and for catering parties for Robert de Niro, NIAF and New Orleans feast, will teach you how to make mozzarella, and let you taste at the same time.

Price: $25 per person.

For information and reservation CLICK HERE.


Tour starts at 10:00am at Gino's Pastry (580 E 187th St Bronx)

For information and reservation please contact us at:

[masked]

results.description:
We'll start out from an established subway line, the Lexington Avenue line,. The meeting point is on Lexington Ave and 77th St. below at the downtown side by the booth attendant. We will then walk south to the new Met extension, the Breuer, then to the new Apple Store . We’ll then go East towards the East River and then make our way West and North while enjoying the old architecture on some of these amazing old masterpieces (a school, a church, 2 libraries and several residential buildings). We'll then walk on second avenue to see some of the new structures that are related to the development of the second avenue subway.
We will end the tour on Fifth Avenue by Central Park and near the Metropolitan Museum of Art. as well as the Onassis Reservoir which was once known as the Croton Reservoir. I will relay the history of Central Park as well as the history of the Old Croton Aqueduct (as this once was an active reservoir for NYC). Please note the $15 MeetUp Member charge per person for this special tour. Discount price for students and senior citizens is offered at $12. This tour's value is actually $250 (for 10 people) as that is my charge for most of my private tours. Kindly provide me with exact payment at the venue. Like my other walks, I do not plan to cancel the walk as this is a multi group event. Also since I set a 20 person limit, please cancel your RSVP if you decide your initial plans have changed. You can then enjoy some FREE or pay-as-you wish museums.

Please feel free to text or call me at[masked] with any questions. Enjoy,
Cindy-NYCindyTours.com

results.description:
Hi everyone,

Please be there 15 minutes earlier so you can get set up, and bring a white and a red t-shirt.

If this game is full click here for our calendar and see other game slots!

Thank you,

Paul

Details Below:

------------------------------------------------------

Game style and Rules:

1. HAVE FUN!!! It's SOCCER

2. We'll play (2) 30-minute games.

3. We will divide into teams based on everyone's experience and skills.

4. No ball hogging.

5. Please use turf shoes or sneakers. 6. The games are very laid back; rough play, tackles or sliding are not allowed and will not be tolerated.

7. We'll play with corner kicks and throw-ins and 6'x15' big goals. Rotate goalies

8. If you arrive late to the game, you would have to wait until the game in progress is finished to join your team. Inserting people in the middle of the game disrupts the flow of the game, and it's not fair to players that arrived on time.

Field Location:The field is located on the corner of West 134th street and Amsterdam Ave. Click on this Google link for location: Click here.

Directions: By train: 1 train to 137th St. City College Station

Time: The game will start at the scheduled time sharp. Please be there 15 minutes earlier so we can get set up.

Late arrivals:

If you arrive late to the game, you would have to wait until the game in progress is finished to join your team. Inserting people in the middle of the game disrupts the flow of the game, and it's not fair to players that arrived on time.

Fee:

Please pay the fee through paypal. Part of the proceeds go to NYC SOCCER KIDS (we already donated new soccer balls). It also goes to pay for the site admistration, meet-up fees, cones, soccer balls, and the new goals.

Please bring:

A white t-shirt and a red t-shirt to differentiate players of each team. The filed is turf so please bring turf shoes, sneakers or all terrain shoes; cleats are not allowed!

Cancellations/Refunds:

If you won't be able to make it to the game, please change your RSVP to "NO" 48 hours before kickoff time to receive a credit for any future game (please email me to issue the credit) This is done to give other members a chance to take your spot. Thank you!

Waiting List:

If all the spots are taken, please get on the waiting list. If a spot opens up and you are on the waiting list, an automated e-mail will be sent letting you know that a spot has just openned :). You can also check our calendar for other games. Click here for calendar.

Weather Policy: Games will be cancelled if the weather conditions are severe such as snow, sleet or thunderstorms. If the game is cancelled I will send out an e-mail the morning of the game. Please check your e-mail. If you are unsure, or can't get to your e-mail, you can also text or call Mane at[masked]-6601.

See you on the pitch!

Paul

results.description:
This week we will meet to discuss the latest, most exciting  discovery in Physics in a generation...gravitational waves.  The first half of the talk will be non-technical, describing the instruments which were used to make the discovery, LIGO, what causes gravitational waves, and what the heck it means for Spacetime to deform in the first place!

Here are some good short introductory videos on the subject....

http://www.nature.com/news/all-you-need-to-know-about-gravitational-waves-1.14886


https://m.youtube.com/watch?v=s06_jRK939I


And some background reading...

https://www.ligo.caltech.edu


https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gravitational_wave


In the second half of the discusion we will try to present linearized gravitational theory and the gravitational wave equation. I am not sure how far we will get (because it is a LOT) but here is a reading and some lectures which take an unconventional approach to the gravitational wave presentation.  Perhaps this is material for further meetings.

http://www.tat.physik.uni-tuebingen.de/~kokkotas/Teaching/NS.BH.GW_files/GW_Physics.pdf


Kip Thorne's lectures at CalTech are here...(a giant in General Relativity)

https://m.youtube.com/watch?v=9ke9rHq22kg


https://m.youtube.com/watch?v=k9CzuUK1heE


https://m.youtube.com/watch?v=qYgLbDvY-vI


https://m.youtube.com/watch?v=Jd24dYLXOas


I hope to see you there!

results.description:
Wine-making is completed in 3 steps/sessions in over just 8 weeks. All wine-making steps can be accompanied with food and wine snacks, even BYO wine.

http://yourownwinery.com/


The three wine-making steps:

Step One - Select Wines & Start Fermentation
Start with sampling wines at the free tasting bar to select the wines we wish to make. As a group, we will choose 2 different wines. Both can be made without sulfite (preservatives). We will then mix the wine juice with ingredients, most importantly wine yeast, to start fermentation wherein the yeast converts the sugar in the wine juice to alcohol. This step takes 45-60 minutes. 

Step Two - Stabilizing & Clearing
Add ingredients to stop fermentation and facilitate clearing (falling of sediments to the bottom of the wine container), and de-gassing the wine with a blending tool using a cordless drill. It is not necessary that all of us attend this part of the process. This step takes 30-45 minutes.

Step Three - Bottling
The most fun step. Fill the bottles, cork, and label. Takes 60-90 minutes, or as long as you need. Your wine is ready to enjoy at this step, so we will bring in some food and snacks, and make it an extraordinary social event. And at the end – we take home our finished Wines.

Wine-making is done in “small batches”, which consists of making 6 gallons of the same wine, which yields 28 full-size (750ml) bottles. We will each leave with 5 1/2 bottles.

There is a 10 person limit on this event. JoAnn Naklicki will be hosting and will write the winery one check. Cost is $63.50 per person. To secure your spot, you must send a check to JoAnn Naklicki by February 15th. As you register for the event, you will be sent JoAnn's address.
results.name: Wine-Making!

results.description:
One Tour, Three Very Different Experiences: Free with suggested donation of $1 - $2 dollars to defray organizer's expenses.  RSVP's begin Thursday March 24th at 1:00pm. 

Bring a snack, water and wear comfortable shoes as in total we will be walking a good five miles.  We may have an option to eat afterwards at a local German  eateryor other Glendale neighborhood restaurant.  Please try and take care of business in Downtown Forest Hills - where the tour begins. Forest Park has restrooms.

We'll start out with a stroll through Forest Hills Gardens - the first planned garden community in the United States. This unique community consisting of over 800 free-standing and attached houses and 11 apartment buildings as well as churches, parks and storefronts, dates from 1909, when architect Grosvenor Atterbury and landscape architect Frederick Law Olmsted Jr.–-son of Frederick Law Olmsted, landscape architect who helped design Central Park–-were commissioned to plan a new town. 

We'll walk through part of Forest Park where we'll see Spring come alive with blooms and birds. Forest Park consists of 500 acres including 165 acres of trees, and in total is nearly 2/3 the size of Central Park.

Adjacent to the park is the Glendale neighborhood was originally the farming town of Fresh Ponds chartered by the Dutch West India Company in 1642. Farming began to die out, and textile factories and breweries became the town’s major employers. Each boom in industry attracted a new wave of immigrants of German decent. Today, the community is home to the largest German-American population in not only Queens, but also in all of the City of New York. But their presence is also dwindling, while immigrants from Asia and the Caribbean are now settling in Glendale in sizeable numbers.
results.how_to_find_us: E,F,R,G to 71st Street Continental Avenue, Forest Hills. We'll meet outside the Starbucks.
results.name: Forgotten Queens: Exploring Forest Hills Gardens, Glendale and Forest Park

results.description:
This week we'll begin turning our attention to three challenging mind states we all encounter at the center of the ever turning Wheel of Life.

Like most of us, you may get the feeling of being stuck on the constantly circling Wheel or wandering across the same terrain again and again. That experience is known as samsara. Our investigation over the next few weeks will focus on those challenging central states of samsara as well as the states that represent the freedom from those challenges.

The three mind states we find at the hub of the Wheel are Delusion/Ignorance, Hatred and Greed. They are potent enough forces in our life to be called the Three Poisons. Each contributes to keeping the Wheel turning, and when we investigate fully, we can see that all of our dissatisfaction and suffering and unskillful actions can be traced back to one of these three elements.

Conversely, each of these poisons is counterbalanced by a state that represents freedom or liberation from the negative influences. Freedom from Delusion and Ignorance is Wisdom, freedom from Hatred is Loving-Kindness and Compassion and freedom from Greed is Generosity. 

We'll take each of these pairings in turn beginning with Delusion/Ignorance and its counterbalance of Wisdom.

I hope you'll share your Saturday morning with us.

Class Structure:  

Each class begins with a very brief guided meditation of gathering and quieting followed by a topical teaching and an expanded guided mindfulness meditation. There is time for discussion and Q&A.  Please note that while there is benefit in participating in regular sittings and practice, you do not have to attend every class to find value. 

Fee by donation: Suggested starting donation is $10 and your generosity is greatly appreciated.  No one is ever turned away for lack of funds.  The donation box is on the sign-in table.
results.name: Wheel of Life - Delusion/Ignorance and Wisdom

Calling all poets! Jersey City Writers is now offering a weekly poetry workshop. 

This workshop will start by critiquing 2-3 poems, one by each person signed up ahead of time. The workshop will end, if time permits, with one 10 minute writing prompt (an idea to incorporate into a poem written on the spot).  Poets who sign up to be workshopped must email Sarah poem by 10am Friday so she can print copies for the group. To sign up for a workshop in advance, please contact Sarah Jewell at [masked]. 

While workshopping poems, we will “mind our P’s and Q’s” by Praising first what works in a poem, and then Questioning what might be improved. This helps to keep the feedback positive and constructive. If you are new to critiquing poetry, please see these guidelines:
http://triadwriters.org/inspiration/guidelines-critique-of-poem/

Greetings Cooking NYC Meetup Members!  Long time, no see. Sorry for the last minute notice.


Not exactly a 'cooking' meetup - but we're still experiencing food - from the ground up!

Join us this Saturday (4/2) for a fun-filled day of farm chores with foodies and urban farming enthusiasts throughout the city at La Finca Del Sur Farm. ( Just a 5 minute train ride from midtown Manhattan on express 4/5 train)

La Finca Del Sur is one of the largest urban farms in New York City!  2.5 acre urban farm oasis overflowing with tons of sun and fresh air!   

Saturday's highlight activities: Spreading mulch, harvest vegetables, How to Compost , Learn about cold weather crops,  How to start seeds for the upcoming growing season, growing food basics and much more!

Light refreshments and drinks will be available!

All rsvps will receive my cellphone # closer to the date or just walk inside the farm and ask for Gina

Directions: Fast and easy commute - Take the 4 or 5 express train to 138thST/Grand Concourse. Walk out the station – Farm is located across the street, behind the cul de sac and fence.

A half-day interactive workshop for women, that will help you to build a productive mindset, find and express your voice and navigate your entrepreneurial journey.

Takeaways 

• Build inner self-confidence that will reflect in your personal and professional life 

• Identify the core reason why you want to be an entrepreneur 

• Engage with other women who are game changes 

• Discover the hidden energy that is called HUSTLE! 

• Overcome your fear of letting your voice be heard! 

Brought to you by: 
Illicit Mind Inc 
Black Girl Magik 
Badass Women's Society 


Agenda:
Check in (10:45am-11am) 


Welcome + Panel (11am SHARP -11:30am) 
Learn Hustle Hacks from current female entrepreneurs who are changing the game! 
Panelist: Sharon Beason, Pasha Cook, Seema Alexander, Vix Reitano, Jen Glantz 


Lunch + Networking (11:35am-12pm) 
This will be your chance to meet the panelists, engage with attendees and grab some food! 

Mindset Magik (12:05pm-12:45pm) 
Black Girl Magik founder, Shydeia will lead a workshop that will show you the power and impact that your mindset has on your overall success. 


Find your VOICE (12:50pm-1:30pm) 
Badass Women's Society founders, Olive + Minna will engage you in a series of activities that will allow you to find your voice, build inner self-confidence and express yourself! 


Why WE Hustle (1:40pm-2:20pm) 
Illicit Mind Inc's founder, Georgie-Ann teach you why as an entrepreneur it's important to find and release your inner hustle, steps of how to release it and hustle hacks that every entrepreneur should know.

results.description:
Waiting List: The day before an event we tend to have a lot of people drop out so do not be discouraged if you're on the waiting list--there's a good chance you'll be able to join.

Attending List: Please remember that the RSVP list closes at 5pm the day before an event. If you change your RSVP to NO after that time or are a no-show, someone on the waiting list could be left out. We take that very seriously.

Club Hours: Gotham Archery has reserved space for us from 11:00am to 1:00pm. Those are the official club hours. Everyone is free to stay longer at the regular range rate.

First-Timers: If it is your first time at Gotham Archery, you will have to take a safety & intro lesson class from the range staff and demonstrate safe shooting. No exceptions. Please arrive 15 minutes early; the class will start promptly at 11:00am.

Public Transportation: Gotham Archery is located at 480 Baltic St (Brooklyn, NY 11217) in Gowanus. It's a few blocks south-west of the Atlantic Av-Barclays Ctr train station. The 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, B, D, N, Q and R trains all stop there.

By car from LI:You can take the LIE, Northern State or Southern State to either Jackie Robinson or the BQE.  Set your GPS to 480 Baltic Street, NY, 11217.  The parking on Sat. AM isn't bad at all: you may have to circle the block once or twice.  The building is painted in a somber yellow ochre.

BUT: please consider car pooling or training it: the drive is awful; the train is lovely.  Most LI LIRR stations suspend parking fees on Sat and Sun.

You change at Jamaica and get in at the Atlantic Terminal in Brooklyn-- walk south for about 7-8 minutes to Baltic -- go right.  Gotham is on the left.  The first time you walk here, you should have your GPS active.


 Range Costs: Make sure to mention when you pay for range time you are shooting with the NYC Archery Group to get the CLUB ONLY rate: $20 for two hours of shooting, $5 for equipment (plus sales tax). These discounts only apply during official club hours.

 Club Equipment: At this time we cannot guarantee there will be club equipment to borrow, so please plan accordingly. One of us will post in the comments if that changes.

 See you on the shooting line!

results.description:
Here's an opportunity to do something good while having some fun.  First we'll meet and get to know each other a bit.  Next, we'll circulate throughout the bookstore, to check out what's on the shelves.  Then we'll regroup, with our purchases, and we'll explain what we picked and why.  What do you usually read, and how do these purchases fit in?

Each attendee must buy at least one book, and each attendee must buy something from the cafe.  The cafe serves coffee, tea, pastries, and sandwiches.  100% of the store's profits go to Housing Works, which is a community of people living with and affected by HIV/AIDS. HW's mission is to end the dual crises of homelessness and AIDS through relentless advocacy, the provision of lifesaving services, and entrepreneurial businesses that sustain their efforts. 

Note, this is optional but, if you'd like, you may bring some of your old books and donate them to Housing Works.  HW accepts books, CDs, DVDs, and LPs in saleable condition, with no major damage.  HW does not accept VHS, audio cassettes, magazines (except for literary magazines), encyclopedias, or any dated material such as travel guides that are more than a year old.


Attendees are responsible for paying for food and books. 


If something comes up and you can't attend, please change your RSVP status as soon as possible.  Given the small size of this meetup group, no-show's would be a big loss.

results.description:
We'll be on a 90-minute tour, led by a U.S. Park Ranger, of - - - 

The African Burial Ground National Monument

http://www.nps.gov/afbg/images/2-Aerial-Shot.jpghttp://www.nps.gov/afbg/images/860489_641386442577077_2280804692705056712_o.jpghttp://www.nps.gov/afbg/images/4-2-Outdoor-Memorial.JPGhttp://www.nps.gov/afbg/images/5-1-Exhibits_2.JPG

On the eve of the American Revolution, New York City was second only to Charleston, South Carolina as an urban center of slavery. In 1991, during excavations for a new federal building in Manhattan’s Financial District, a colonial-era burial ground containing the remains of an estimated 15-20,000 Africans was discovered. Today, a memorial commemorates those interred in the African Burial Ground, and a visitor center addresses the history of African-descended people in early New York as well as the struggle to preserve the burial ground itself.

The African Burial Ground Visitor Center is the most-visited of all New York City’s National Park Service sites since its opening in February, 2010. Though the bones of those buried at the African Burial Ground were first discovered by the General Services Administration (GSA) in 1991, it took a great deal of time and effort before both the memorial and the visitor center came to fruition. 

The GSA was able to identify what it had discovered, thanks to a 1755 map of New York, where the location was marked as the “Negros Burial Ground.” The GSA then hired a team of archaeologists, but elected to pursue both excavation and construction, thus destroying some remains in the process. After Fox News broke the story of what was occurring at the site, an outcry arose from black New Yorkers. Construction was halted due to protests and political interventions. 

In 1993, the site was placed on the National Register of Historic Places, and an archaeological team from Howard University undertook the project of studying the 419 exhumed remains. The project lasted 10 years, till 2003, the same year in which the GSA struck an agreement with the National Park Service, creating the Development and Public Investment of the Exterior Memorial and the Interpretive Center. On October 4, 2003, a re-internment ceremony involving eight cities, 10,000 participants, and lasting for five days occurred, beginning in Washington, D.C., and ending in New York City.

The federal Ted Weiss building, where the visitor center and part of the memorial are contained, was completed in 2005. (Six artworks commissioned as an extension of the memorial line the lobby. Images and more information are available here: http://www.africanburialground.gov/ABG_Artwork.htm ) Artist Rodney Leon beat out 61 competitors in the memorial design competition. An official opening and dedication was held on October 7, 2007, and was attended by Mayor Michael Bloomberg and Congressman Charles B. Rangel, among others. 

The visitor center, which opened in 2010, seeks to educate visitors on four topics:     

1) The archaeological studies and findings made by Howard University’s team at the burial ground.

In the archaeological section, visitors can use interactive touch screens to consider relevant questions, such as, “What can bones tell us?” and receive detailed answers. Replicas of artifacts found buried with the bodies (all original artifacts have been re-buried) are on display. Four hundred and nineteen skeletons had been uncovered before excavation was stopped, and a large, lighted panel displays photographs of the bones. Each burial is marked by a number, with the age and sex of the buried listed. The exhibit notes that few of the slaves interred here lived past age 45; nearly half of those excavated had not lived past the age of 12. 

2) The lives of slaves in the 18th century.

The historical section, which focuses on the way slaves lived in the 18th century, takes a more personalized, rather than scientific approach. Descriptions of work, newspaper ads calling for the return of runaways, and the listing of laws that restricted the movement of slaves are all present, conveying the daily realities and hardships that the enslaved faced. The stories of individuals are also displayed on panels, giving visitors a fuller picture of those buried at the African Burial Ground. In the center of the exhibit are life-sized models gathered around coffins, meant to evoke what a funeral held at the African Burial Ground may have been like. A dramatization of a funeral is also shown in a short film.

3) Modern-day African-American and African culture.

The third exhibit in the visitor’s center concentrates on both present-day Africa and New York, discussing how modern African-American New Yorkers carry on the traditions of their ancestors, and displaying artifacts from countries such as Nigeria and Mali. 


4) The campaign that led to the eventual creation of the African Burial Ground memorial and visitor center.

The fourth and final exhibit launches into a timeline of how the African Burial Ground visitor’s center and monument came to be, from 1989 to the present. Scrapbooks filled with newspaper clippings about the protest are available for reading, and a video of the re-internment cemetery plays on a loop. In a sub-section titled “Why our heritage matters,” visitors are also able to select and watch interviews with different people who were involved in the fight to have the burial ground recognized. They are also able to leave their thoughts about the exhibit via recording on a webcam or writing on index cards. 

The memorial is located on a quiet block, just around the corner from the visitor’s center. The space, which is open to the public, is dominated by Rodney Leon’s black granite slab, on which is inscribed, “For all those who were lost, For all those who were stolen, For all those who were left behind, For all those who were not forgotten”. To the right of the slab rest the seven mounds where the excavated remains and artifacts were re-interred. To the left, partially formed by Leon’s slab, is the libation chamber, a reflective space meant to invoke the feeling of a ship’s hold. Just beyond is the Circle of the Diaspora, a map which depicts the forced removal of Africans from their homeland to varying parts of the world. 

A sign asks that visitors respect the memorial space, and that they do not eat, run, or talk on cell phones on the ground. When designing the space, Leon intended it to be a “living memorial”—a place to always remember those buried here.

Open Play for Advanced Beginners and Intermediate Players.

Our game starts promptly at 11:30am.  You are welcome to come slightly earlier to change and warm up.

We can accommodate 3 teams, 8 players per team max (double rotation). Rally scoring. Game to 15 when it's 3 teams, Game to 25 when it's 2 teams. 

IMPORTANT - Skill Level Required for our Open Play

Know how to rotate on the court, serve, pass, set, spike and block. Know how to hold your position on the court during defense and offense.  This is meant for players that have experience playing.

Rules will be enforced to protect all players from safety and fun.

Recreational players and beginners can practice on the side or come watch for FREE. We also run a skills clinic to improve your game. Please ask!

If you will be attending for the first time, please check in with me for a quick 3 min assessment. 

Thanks and hope to see you on the court!

May

results.description:
Hip-Hop Hacks is a two-day hackathon for high school students to explore technology's role in hip-hop and how the most popular genre in the world inspires technological innovation.

Click Here To Register

Since its inception, hip-hop has evolved in tandem with technology, from turntables and microphones to mediums like vinyl, compact cassettes, mp3s, and now apps and algorithms.

Students will study the elements of hip-hop, participate in code and music workshops, network with other students, and learn from music- and tech-industry veterans.

results.description:
Hi everyone,

Please be there 15 minutes earlier so you can get set up, and bring a white and a red t-shirt.

If this game is full click here for our calendar and see other game slots!

Thank you,

Paul

Details Below:

------------------------------------------------------

Game style and Rules:

1. HAVE FUN!!! It's SOCCER

2. We'll play (2) 30-minute games.

3. We will divide into teams based on everyone's experience and skills.

4. No ball hogging.

5. Please use turf shoes or sneakers. 6. The games are very laid back; rough play, tackles or sliding are not allowed and will not be tolerated.

7. We'll play with corner kicks and throw-ins and 6'x15' big goals. Rotate goalies

8. If you arrive late to the game, you would have to wait until the game in progress is finished to join your team. Inserting people in the middle of the game disrupts the flow of the game, and it's not fair to players that arrived on time.

Field Location:The field is located on the corner of West 134th street and Amsterdam Ave. Click on this Google link for location: Click here.

Directions: By train: 1 train to 137th St. City College Station

Time: The game will start at the scheduled time sharp. Please be there 15 minutes earlier so we can get set up.

Late arrivals:

If you arrive late to the game, you would have to wait until the game in progress is finished to join your team. Inserting people in the middle of the game disrupts the flow of the game, and it's not fair to players that arrived on time.

Fee:

Please pay the fee through paypal. Part of the proceeds go to NYC SOCCER KIDS (we already donated new soccer balls). It also goes to pay for the site admistration, meet-up fees, cones, soccer balls, and the new goals.

Please bring:

A white t-shirt and a red t-shirt to differentiate players of each team. The filed is turf so please bring turf shoes, sneakers or all terrain shoes; cleats are not allowed!

Cancellations/Refunds:

If you won't be able to make it to the game, please change your RSVP to "NO" 48 hours before kickoff time to receive a credit for any future game (please email me to issue the credit) This is done to give other members a chance to take your spot. Thank you!

Waiting List:

If all the spots are taken, please get on the waiting list. If a spot opens up and you are on the waiting list, an automated e-mail will be sent letting you know that a spot has just openned :). You can also check our calendar for other games. Click here for calendar.

Weather Policy: Games will be cancelled if the weather conditions are severe such as snow, sleet or thunderstorms. If the game is cancelled I will send out an e-mail the morning of the game. Please check your e-mail. If you are unsure, or can't get to your e-mail, you can also text or call Mane at[masked]-6601.

See you on the pitch!

Paul

results.description:
Dear NYC Live Streamers:

Hello and welcome again to NYC Live Streamers Group!  Welcome all Blabbers, Periscopers, Snapchatters, FB Live'ers and other live streamers!

We will be hosting our first in person meetup for Live Streamers in NYC this Saturday, April 2. 


This is being co-organized with Zef Zan, whom you may know from Blab and me, Frank Clark.  Zef and I met through blab.im, and we are partners in producing an online conference for startups called Startup Con Live.  Zef and I have  not actually met in person and are excited to finally meet in person on Saturday!

Paul was a recent live stream guest with us on Startup Con Live on blab and is an expert on digital marketing with Facebook ads.  He has outstanding content. If you want to see that interview, and all of the Startup Con Live interviews, please click here to get access:  www.bit.ly/startupcon2.  To learn more about Paul, you can visit his website here:  http://www.paulramondo.com/


We will be meeting at a restaurant, probably a Malaysian restaurant in the Greenwich Village/NYU neighborhood.  This is subject to change and we will send you the final location by email on Friday of this week.  There is not a separate fee to attend, but you will be responsible for the cost of your meal.  Guesstimate  is about $25-$35 or so.


To learn more about Zef, you can follow her on Blab at https://blab.im/zef_zan. 

To learn more about Frank Clark you can follow me on Blab at https://blab.im/FrankClarkCoach or at www.frankclarkcoaching.com.

Our twitter handles are also the same: @zef_zan and @frankclarkcoach. 

We look forward to meeting you in person!


All the best,

Frank Clark

Organizer

The Giant Stairs is an excellent hike in the Palisades along the Hudson River! It not only offers some nice trails, but there is a great section of rocks to scramble over where we can practice our movement skills!

Come out and play! 

Patrick

results.description:
Have you ever wanted to try shooting with studio strobes? Or, do you own strobes, but still have questions about using them? Do you hate when these topics are discussed using terms you never understand? If so, this is the Meetup for you.  

This is a hands-on, in studio workshop for those looking to work with strobe lighting.  This workshop will cover the basics of using strobes.   Some topics that will be covered are:


• Camera settings


• Light meters and metering light


• Shooting tethered 


• Different types of strobes


• Strobe position 


• 1 light and multi-light setups


• Lighting modifiers 


The purpose of this workshop is to hopefully get people more comfortable shooting with studio strobes and to answer any questions that you may have. 


Participants will also have the opportunity to shoot with their own cameras to have some examples to take home. 

The investment for this workshop is $25.  A $5 deposit is required to reserve your spot and $20 will be collected the day of the event.  Space is limited.  If this session fills up, I will consider adding another session based on interest. 


Please contact me directly if you have any questions. [masked]

Cheers

Devon
results.name: Shooting with strobes 101

This event sold out very quickly the last time we did it so if you'd like to attend, please purchase a ticket ASAP. This is a great informal event where you can experience the American Museum of Natural History and at the same time, meet fun new people and make some new friends

The tour starts at 2pm, however we will have a pre-mingle starting at NOON at a local bar/pub close to the museum (location announced only to those who registered/paid) where we will introduce you to the other attendees and give you admission tickets to the museum.

We'll have a dedicated tour guide for our group that will give us an hour tour providing a general overview of the Museum’s treasures. Afterwards, we will experience some of the fantastic shows. Your ticket includes:

12pm-1:30pm - Pre-Mingle & Museum ticket pick up

2pm - Group Highlights Tour

3:30pm - Imax Movie : Secret Ocean or other

4:30pm - Exhibit - Spiders Alive

$55.75 (limited # available, price will go up as event gets closer)


*NOTE: You must pick up your tickets at the pre-mingle location no later than 1:30. If you arrive after 1:30 you will not be able to find the group.

results.description:
A free one-day conference for creatives working along the intersections of design, art, and technology.

The conference features talks on interdisciplinary practice, one-on-one portfolio review sessions (spots are limited - http://bit.ly/catportfolio), and opportunities for social play.

Part of the Creative Arts & Technology Festival. You may also be interested in The NJ Arcade (3/30) - http://njarcade2016mar.eventbrite.com/
__________________________________________________

SCHEDULE

12:00pm: Portfolio Reviews / Coffee & Refreshments
2:00pm: Conference Talks & Panels
3:30pm: Intermission with Gigantic Mechanic
4:00pm: Conference Talks & Panels
6:00pm: Dinner & Closing Reception with Gigantic Mechanic
__________________________________________________

CONFERENCE TALKS

A single-track conference featuring conversations on the interdisciplinary nature of creative work.

Featured speakers:

FLASH ROSENBERG: Awareness Engineer, Attention Span for Hire, Live-Drawing

OMAR SHAKIR: Narrative Director at Avalanche Studios

SHAWN ALEXANDER ALLEN: Independent Game Developer (Treachery in Beatdown City)

ROSSANA VILLAFLOR: B-girl & Cofounder at Community for Urban Dance & Art

MITU KHANDAKER-KOKORIS: Independent Game Developer (The Tiniest Shark)

JASON EPPINK: Curator of Digital Media at the Museum of the Moving Image

More to be announced soon!

__________________________________________________

PORTFOLIO REVIEWS

Portfolio Reviews are a chance for emerging professionals to get constructive feedback, build professional relationships, and network with fellow creatives.

Apply to be a participant here - http://bit.ly/catportfolio

Slots are very limited. Early application is recommended.

Participants receive up to 4 one-on-one portfolio review sessions. Each session may be up to 15 minutes.

Consult with a diverse pool of reviewers. Fields represented include game design & development, animation, music, sound design, and more. Some of our Portfolio Reviewers include:

Katie Better, motion capture animator at Rockstar Games
David Or, senior game developer at Arkadium
Alyssa Menes, independent composer & sound designer
Lawrence Mascia, founder & lead designer at Goodnight Games
Will Varner, illustration director at BuzzFeed
Jessie Contour, freelance artist & 3D animator
Winnie Song, independent game developer
Peter Zummo, musician, composer, & producer

More portfolio reviewers to be announced soon! __________________________________________________

GIGANTIC MECHANIC
Gigantic Mechanic is bringing fun, engaging experiences to the Creative Arts & Technology Conference through real-world, physical & social play. Art Boy Sin: Grab letters. Grab tape. Make street poetry.
Scattershot: Two buttons. A hundred friends. Total chaos.
TetraGrams: Collaborative tetris... and tangrams ... at the same time.

__________________________________________________

INCLUSIVITY STATEMENT

This is a safe and inclusive space where we respect people of all backgrounds. Please help us all be mindful of our speech and behavior. Harassment of any form is not tolerated, and in certain cases violators may be asked to leave the premises. If there's an issue, please let the event organizers know.
__________________________________________________

GETTING TO BLOOMFIELD COLLEGE

Westminster Hall & Van Fossan Theatre
63 Fremont St. (Fremont St. & Austin Pl.)
Bloomfield, NJ

Train: Take the Montclair-Boonton Line to Bloomfield Station (~30 minute trip from NY Penn Station). Schedule here - https://www.njtransit.com/pdf/rail/R0030.pdf

Car: Bloomfield College is near exit 148 on the Garden State Parkway. Street parking is free on weekends. Free parking is also available in the main campus lot, located at 225 Liberty Street. Bus: The NJ Transit 11, 27, 28, 29, 72, and GO28 lines all stop in Bloomfield

results.description:
THE WALK IS ON. IF THE MAJORITY PREFERS WE WILL STICK TO THE ORIGINAL ITINERARY DESPITE THE RAIN. IF NOT WE WILL EAT IN THE MET CAFETERIA AND SEE A FEW EXHIBITS THERE BEFORE LUNCH. THAT WILL MINIMIZE OUR TIME OUTDOORS UNTIL THE RAIN STOPS AT 3 PM, AS FORECAST.  YOU CAN BRING YOUR OWN LUNCH IF YOU WISH. ADMISSION TO THE MET (PAY WHAT YOU WISH) GETS YOU INTO THE MET BREUER.

Let's explore the Upper East Side, where we'll visit the Met Breuer (pay what you wish), the Metropolitan Museum's newly opened showcase for Modern art in the former home of the Whitney Museum. We'll also tour a free museum of ancient civilization, currently showing Designing Identity: The Power of Textiles in late Antiquity; the magnificent Ukrainian Institute, featuring four floors of art ($5); some of the swankiest art galleries in town; and possibly more. We'll eat lunch in Central Park (see details below). 


PLEASE READ THE FOLLOWING DETAILS, SO YOU'RE PROPERLY PREPARED:


DISTANCE: About 2 miles.

PACE: Moderate (about 3 blocks in 4 minutes), NOT SLOW. If you want to stroll rather than walk moderately, this is NOT the right event for you!

LUNCH: Bring your own--you cannot buy lunch in the park. We'll eat there starting at around 2 to 2:30 PM. If it's raining we'll eat in the Met Cafeteria, where you can still bring your own food, though I'd encourage you to buy at least a drink as a courtesy. Admission to the Met (pay what you wish) gets you into the Met Breuer

COST: $2, in part to cover Meetup's organizer fee, plus pay what you wish at the Met or Met Breuer museum, $5 for the Ukrainian Institute (special group rate, normally $8) and whatever food you buy if we have lunch at the Met. You can hang out in the park for a while if you'd rather skip the Institute. 

ENDING TIME: 5 to 5:30 PM, but you can leave earlier, of course.

TRANSPORTATION: 4,5,6 train to 86th St. and Lexington. For details consult tripplanner.mta.org as well as a subway map, since the site does not always list the optimal routes. 

WAITING LIST:  You can see it below the main list on the right side of this page on a computer but possibly not on other devices. And be patient: there will be many cancellations, especially at the last minute. But please don't sign up just as a placeholder if you're not reasonably sure you'd like to attend. Placeholders fill up the lists and discourage other people from coming.

results.description:
April 2, 1-4:30pm
MARNI NIXON’s Encores Master Class
Recording artist & Broadway singing great, Marni Nixon guides singers and the audience through an enjoyable afternoon of familiar music from Broadway & The American Songbook.

American soprano Marni Nixon’s legendary career is as broad as it is versatile.  Having achieved world-class stardom in opera, musical theater, and popular music genres, Ms. Nixon has been performing her way into the ears and hearts of audiences around the world for more than five decades. 

From a very young age, Ms. Nixon’s perfect pitch and impeccable sight-reading skills enabled her to perform with the utmost precision the most challenging vocal works of the 20th century; and her incredible musicianship made her one of the most sought-after singers by legends such as Leonard Bernstein and Igor Stravinsky, both with whom she worked and personally knew.  As a young singer in the classical world, Ms. Nixon accomplished more than most aspiring opera singers dream to in a lifetime: performing roles such as Violetta Valéry (La Traviata), Périchole (La Périchole), Musetta (La Bohéme), Nanetta (Falstaff), and Zerbinetta (Ariadne auf Naxos) with world-renowned opera companies including Seattle Opera, San Francisco Opera, and Los Angeles Opera, and the Public Broadcasting Station’s Televised Opera performances – to name a very few.

Ms. Nixon has widely performed as a concert and oratorio soloist in works such as Bach’s BWV 198: Laß, Fürstin, laß noch einen Strahl and Canteloube’s Chants d’Auvergne; and has appeared with the New York Philharmonic, the Los Angeles Philharmonic, the Cleveland Orchestra, Toronto Symphony Orchestra, the London Symphony Orchestra, and the Israel Philharmonic Orchestra.  A champion of contemporary works, Ms. Nixon has performed Schoenberg's Pierrot Lunaire, Hovanhess’s Avak, the Healer, and Peter Maxwell Davies's Miss Donnithorne's Maggot; as well as premiered Pierre Boulez'sImprovisation sur Mallarmé I under Bernstein.  Ms. Nixon also toured with famed illustrious Liberace and the beloved musical entertainer Victor Borge, bringing musical and comedic improvisation to eager audiences across the country.

Outside of the classical world, Marni Nixon is most recognized as the singing voice for actresses Deborah Kerr in The King and I, Natalie Wood in West Side Story, Audrey Hepburn in My Fair Lady, and Marilyn Monroe in Gentleman Prefer Blondes.  Often called “ghosting,” Marni Nixon’s singing work for actresses behind the silver screen earned her the title of “The Voice of Hollywood.”  Stepping out into the spotlight, Ms. Nixon went on to perform dozens of roles such as Sister Sophia (film and stage versions of The Sound of Music), Heidi Schiller (Follies), and Guido's Mother (Nine).  She has won several awards for her performance of Edna in Taking My Turn, also the first off-Broadway musical to be filmed for PBS’s Great Performances series.  Ms. Nixon has, in fact, earned numerous awards for her outstanding performances, including Grammy Awards in the category of Best Classical Performance, Vocal Soloist for her recordings of 9 Early Songs: The Cabaret Songs of Arnold Schoenberg and Copland: 8 Poems of Emily Dickinson; 4 Emmy Awards for her performances on Boomerang, a children’s television show with a spectacular 25-year run; as well as her most recent Peabody Award for Outstanding Excellence in American Music.

As evidenced by her successful tours as a concert artist throughout Europe, Ms. Nixon has devoted much of her time to reviving the art of the song recital.  She inspires a new generation of talent as close to her heart as her own accomplished son Andrew Gold – musical director for recording artist Linda Ronstandt, and writer of the Golden Girls theme song “Thank You for Being a Friend” – and as far-reaching as the countless young singers and actors from all genres around the world.  Ms. Nixon currently dispenses her invaluable expertise and vivacious charm through private teaching, as well as leading master classes and workshops across the country.

results.name: Marni Nixon's ENCORES Master Class

results.description:
Many members have been asking for our Saturday Figure Drawing Session.

Join us for three hours of figure drawing in the heart of The Flatiron District.

This session is open to sketchers of all levels.


What makes our sessions different? 

• We work in a large, clean, well-lit space. 

• Sketchers can concentrate because our room is quiet while the model is posing.

• (Latecomers can be seated at a break.) 

• Every hour we take a break to look each others drawings (if you choose to put yours out.) This is a nonjudgmental and very valuable part of the session. 

• This is a three hour drawing session to work from a live (nude) model.   

• We start with 5 minute poses and work up to 20 minute poses by the end of the session. We take a 5 minute break every 20 minutes. 

• There are seats for everyone tables and several light weight easels.  

• Access to a sink is available for watercolor artist.

• Bring your own materials (no oil or acrylic paint and no sprays please.)

Our amazing space!

As always if you have any questions please feel free to email me. I look forward to seeing you there. 

Simon

This class is a basic introduction to physical computing with Arduino.

To keep things simple and explain things at length, we have limited the number of topics in this class to the very basics. Our goal learn the basics of Arduino development and construct a working pulse-oximeter. Sign up for this class if that sounds appealing to you. 

Some experience with electronics, programming, or both, is useful, but not required.

You will learn:

• How to connect the Arduino to your computer 

• How to blink an LED 

• Create a pulse-oximeter sensor with infrared IR emitter and receiver

The class fee includes a parts kit with an Arduino compatible board and all the other parts you need. You MUST bring a laptop running Windows, Linux or Mac OS X that is capable of running Arduino. No refunds will be given if you forget a laptop.

All levels practice. Coached by Granger.

This practice is about water polo. Emphasis is on playing and learning the game by playing. Some of us have been playing since childhood. Others have picked it up as adults. We're friendly and inclusive, but we play hard.

Requirements:

-You have to join New York Recreation. $75 for 6 months for access to all rec centers and pools in the city. If you're under 25, you pay $25 for 1 year. http://www.nycgovparks.org/programs/recreation-centers/membership

-Beginners are welcome, but you must be a good swimmer.

-You MUST bring a lock for a gym locker.

-You should bring an athletic bathing suit, goggles, and a towel. Bring a swim cap if you have long hair.

results.description:
Note: This meetup has been rescheduled from the original date of 2/13/16. 

Hi there -- This is the weekend version of our first book club meeting! It's basically the same as the weekday meetup, just scheduled in addition so that those of us who can't make it during the week can still take part. Here's some more information... 

I'm a new stay-at-home mom in the Westchester area looking to meet other moms with infants. I've always wanted to join a book club but it was tough while working full-time and even harder now with a baby. So why don't we try to get together after the holidays in early 2016 and start our own? Moms AND babies will be welcome (expecting moms too, of course!), and don't put too much pressure on yourself if you can't finish the assigned books. I'll try to pick some with Audible recordings (GREAT service to use while at home with a little one) and even movies so that those of us with limited time can still join in discussion. And hey, if you don't get to the book at all, that's ok -- this is about meeting other moms and their kids through a fun activity. 

For our first meetup, let's try reading/listening to/watching Wuthering Heights. If you have a Kindle, I think it's a free download, and it looks to be inexpensive on Audible. Also, a great version with Charlotte Riley and Tom Hardy is streaming now on Amazon Prime.
results.name: Book club meet and greet weekend edition! First book: Wuthering Heights

results.description:
This Event: 

The aim of this weekly event is to offer a place where Python developers and learners can come and ask questions or give help. 

Individuals of all programming skill levels are welcome. 

It is suggested that you bring your own laptop. If you don't have access to a laptop and want to attend, please let Paul Logston know and he will see about getting you a laptop for the day.

This event is free. 

This event is not a tutorial. Tutorials hosted by Learn Python NYC are labeled as tutorials.

Resources:

Here are some learning resources and free text editor / IDE suggestions.

https://github.com/logston/NYCPythonSOH/blob/master/resources.rst 

Detailed Directions to us:

As you enter the building located at 568 Broadway, New York, NY 10012 you will need to provide ID and your destination (Fueled Collective, 11th Floor) to the front desk. They will provide you with a sticker badge. Take one of the elevators (located to the right of the front desk) to the 11th floor. We will be in the Deerbrook conference room.
results.how_to_find_us: Show ID at front desk, come up to 11th floor, we are in the Deerbrook conference room!

results.description:
Hi, everyone!

Let's meet up at the Bloomingdale Library next Saturday, April 2 for the 2 p.m. FREE performance of A Time to Dance, a one-woman show, by the wonderfully talented, Libby Skala. Be there by at least 1:45, as Libby is very well known.

In this show, Libby interweaves storytelling, music and dance to portray the dazzling 100 years of her great aunt, Elizabeth Polk, who transcends poverty, artistic repression and the rise of Hitler through the love of dance to become a renowned dance therapy pioneer.

If any of you are considering writing and performing a one-woman or one-man show, don't miss Libby's performance. It will inspire you and hopefully encourage you to follow your dream. She is certainly a performer to emulate. I can vouch for her talent as a writer-performer, as I have seen one of her three shows, Lilia, which was really spectacular. I'm including her performance schedule so you can catch other shows, in various areas, if you cannot attend this one.

Check out her website information regarding her other performances, videos, reviews, etc.: 

A Time to Dance
http://atimetodance.homestead.com

http://www.libbyskala.com/Dates.html - Schedule of events

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=47Z15SpPnrQ

http://atimetodance.homestead.com/reviews.html


I hope to see many of you at this performance, and look forward to going out for coffee and perhaps a nibble on the upper west side!

Cheers,

Anna, Founder/Organizer of STSANY

www.annabartos.com
results.how_to_find_us: Let's meet in the performance space. Ask for directions at the library.

results.description:
Join us for our weekly Underwater Rugby (UWR) practice!

Underwater what? Underwater rugby is probably the most exciting activity you may have ever done. The only 3D sport (apart from Harry Potter’s Quidditch), great endurance, fast, strategic, and above all: extreme fun! Imagine a 13ft-deep pool, 2 baskets on the bottom of each side. Two teams, equipped with fins, mask&snorkel, and a salt-water filled ball. We hold our breath when playing at 3, 5, 13 feet below the surface and pass the ball standing on our heads, swimming sideways and swirling around. Yes, we can tackle the person who carries the ball. But no, no one ever drowned in the 60 years the sport has been around. Ladies and gents are equally welcome - we are co-ed :)

We have all the equipment you need if you want to try. Just let us know and jump with us into the water - we welcome all levels (though you should be able to swim and be comfortable with the idea of swimming under the water - but you don't need to be an expert diver). 

So just send us a quick line and new experiences await - we promise!

Contact Daniel or Rolexi at [masked]

And check out our Facebook profile www.facebook.com/NJ.UWH.UWR/

<a href="http://g.co/maps/ueppk"></a>
results.how_to_find_us: 226 Rome Street, Newark, NJ  Map: http://g.co/maps/ueppk
results.name: Hammerheads Underwater Rugby practice - Saturdays

results.description:
This is the one! The spot I've been hoping you all would be able to come out to at some point but it's soo soo far away for you BK folks. (But worth it!!) Tortilleria Nixtamal is one of those spots that is a hidden oasis in the middle of nowhere that not too many people know about. Out in Corona Queens exists this brightly colored gem tucked around a corner that you could easily miss but shouldn't.


For the uninitiated Nixtamal is the maker of masa for some of the top restaurants in the city. From that masa they make chips, tortillas and other products used in Mexican cooking. Being part factory/part restaurant we get the spoils of getting some of the freshest products available all made in-house.  Outside of their amazing masa based products, the food is simply divine.

One of my favorite things they do is the parrillada molcajete with the "build your own taco" combination option. It both looks and tastes amazing and is a tacoholics wet dream.


Join me for this spring time excursion to Queens for some of the best Mexican food you will ever have. They also sell their products to the public so if you want to purchase some of their amazing chips, masa or salsas that is totally doable.


After having dinner here I plan to take you all to an amazing Italian bakery for some desserts as well as some local street fare in the heart of queens. This will be a great day indeed. Be There!
results.how_to_find_us: Meet me inside of Nixtamal for what will be a grand feast of goodness...
results.name: A Taco Expedition - Tortilleria Nixtamal (Saturday Action)

results.description:
Hi, you Great Dame, you! We hope you can make one of the 5 performances - it's gonna be killah! It's a great cast and the show is really hilarious ... to read what audiences said when I performed it as a solo show and to read the casts bios ... you must check out <a>www.dameslikeus.com!</a>

Here's the deal, if we can fill the house every Saturday in April - there's a strong chance they'll EXTEND us another month ... or more! And the cool part, is the show is always fresh and different since I rotate the monologues and there are TWO casts - each with their own unique interpretations.

And you'll see from the reviews that MEN especially love the show, too! (I almost had to stop one show because a man up front was laughing so hard - I thought he was CHOKING!) So, feel free to bring a guy or three!

There are no reservations at this venue, tickets are at the door. It's first come/first serve situation and there are only 60 seats at cafe tables  so I suggest you get there about 1/2 hour before the show.

It's $20 ($10 cover/$10 minimum) and you get a complimentary glass of champagne. Or for $15 more, you can feast on their fabulous Prix Fix Brunch Menu! (You can check out the venue here and look at their Brunch Menu)


PRUDE WARNING: This is no "granny" show. It doesn't hold back - so there's a fair amount of colorful language. 

LAUGH WARNING: Men, bring your defibrillators  - Women, bring Depends.

Here are some of the earlier REVIEWS!

NEW YORK TIMES

Perfect Women's Night Out! This wonderful show is amazing. I went with 4 good friends and we can't wait to see her again. Don't miss it!

– Stephanie, NY


Laughed my head off -- This must of been what it was like when Judy Holiday performed at the Village Vanguard and later Lily Tomlin at the Blue Angel. Bravo ! It wigged me out.

Alex Adams, Princeton, NJ


Funny from beginning to end showcasing laugh until your sides hurt dialogue. This show is a winner, go and enjoy it.

– Cheryl Restaino,, Pequannock, NJ


Laughter and insights - you don't just see them, you feel them. Francesca becomes her wonderful ensemble of characters with such comfort and warmth that, no matter how outrageous their edge or OMG moments you encounter.....you really like them because deep down Francesca likes them, too. 

It is truly laugh out loud funny -- usually for its cleverness, surprise and insight, but never the result of cheap vulgarity. There are any number of times when the women laugh a lot louder than we men do .... which reminds us that great humor has a foundation of great truths.

This is not stand-up..... this is good writing and any of these characters could have stepped out of a play or novel. Rizzo seems as much in command of fine character driven writing as she is in portraying the characters themselves.

– Leonard Steinbach, New York, NY


A wonderfully fun peek into the lives of women, I loved this rare chance to be a 'fly on the wall. Ms. Rizzo truly pays tribute to them, and she treats them - for all their quirkiness - with respect and love. The result is both comical and heartwarming: a funny comedy aimed at our adult sensibilities.

– MJ Mangan, Ocean Grove, NJ


Laughing till it hurts. I saw this hilarious show twice! Ms. Rizzo’s characters are memorable and owned the sold-out crowd. The woman next to me laughed so hard she dumped a glass of red wine on my pants. Usually, when I leave a good show one or two characters bounce around my mind. After this show several characters stayed in my head leaving me laughing out of context for the next week. Don’t miss this show. 

– Thomas R. Pryor, New York, NY


Dynamite fun for those of us at "a certain age" and beyond! Kudos to Ms Rizzo for a superb performance."

– Carol Yeager, New York, NY


This is definitely a FIVE STAR EXCELLENT show ... go! enjoy! laugh!

– Hillary Rollins, New York, NY and Santa Monica, CA


NEW JERSEY ARTHOUSE - Meetup

Lots of fun watching Francesca move from character to character. Witty monologues! Packed house!

– Marsha, NJ Arthouse


It was funny and brilliantly written!

– Beth Cifone, NJ Arthouse


She was excellent, and had the audience in stitches in recognition of the characters she played, and even the men laughed! I'd be willing to see the show again if at all possible.

– Cristina, NJ Arthouse


I had a great time...I laughed the whole night! 

- Fatima, NJ Arthouse


Francesca was great!!!!

- Dawn Lee, NJ Arthouse


NEW YORK BRAINIACS - Meetup


Francesca was hilarious! It was a fun nite out!

- Madelene, NY Brainiacs


Hysterically funny!

- Deb Maylath, NY Brainiacs


Francesca was a hoot!

-- Ivy, NY Brainiacs

results.description:
Bi-Perspective is the longest-running social, discussion and support group for ALL bisexual/non-monosexual, queer-identified and questioning people meeting in the New York City area.

Monthly meetings are held on the 1st Saturday of every month from 2:30 PM to 4:00 PM at the LGBT Community Center, followed by a convivial Coffee & Desert at a nearby local restaurant. The group provides a warm & friendly, welcoming, caring, SAFE, non-discriminatory environment for everyone who lives, works or plays in the New York City area.

Come visit and share your Feelings, Hopes and Dreams as well as your Fears, Concerns and Uncertainties with us. And of course, Joy and Laughter are always welcome at our meetings too! Bi-Perspective, a great way to meet others from the community and to make new friends in the New York area.

$5 (more if/less if) suggested donation to help defray room-rental cost

results.description:
And so arrives the game we've been waiting for since last November. No matter the Liga standings, this one's about setting the record straight, at their house! And with Zizou now at the helm, this one should be a true classic ... let's do this!

Now, NYC-Madridistas, please note that for we're going back to Playwright for this one, we are testing the Playwright for a Clasico gameday, and given that this our first Clásico at this location, we're all gonna be playing this one by ear a bit, as we get used to the floor layout/capacity ... so, to help out the organizers/staff, please make every effort to RSVP AND arrive as early as possible, by 1:30 PM at the latest!

IMPORTANT INFO REAL MADRID USA TOUR - NJ GAME!: WE WILL BE COLLECTING CASH FOR THIS EVENT AFTER THE CLASICO. If you want to reserve your tickets in the exclusive Penia section for the Real Madrid v Bayern game on August 3rd @ Metlife Stadium stop by after the game at the second floor of the Playwright, in the table area. So if you have not RSVPd yet, what are you waiting for? Penia fondo sur right behind the goal! See Metlife Stadium event details: 

http://www.meetup.com/realmadridnyc/events/229899191/

For further important info on The Clásico event, please continue reading below.

****

Please RSVP ASAP so that Playwright can staff the event appropriately.

****

INSTRUCCIONES EN ESPAÑOL, LEER ABAJO:


Game begins at 2:30 PM EDT, but we STRONGLY encourage you and your guest to please arrive MUCH, MUCH earlier, and enjoy the pre-game atmosphere at Playwright.

Please read:

1. All Madridistas are welcome and entrance is free. Anyone with Barça apparel/flags will NOT be allowed in the bar. Also, if you're an OPM, please do NOT bring any friends/relatives that are Barça fans - there are no excuses for this, and you will not be welcomed inside the bar on ANY level.

2. Official Peña Members (OPM) and ONLY ONE (1) guest will have entrance and placement priority in the upstairs area with RSVP if arriving at least 30 min. before the game. Please bring your membership card! If you are not an official member, you will be directed to remain downstairs if space allows, see below. If you wish to be seated, we recommend you get there early!

3. Basic Meetup Members, tourists, and occasional visitors will be accommodated downstairs on a first-come/first-serve basis. For this group, we recommend that you come at least one (1) to two (2) hours before the game if you wish to be seated at the bar (rest of the downstairs area is stand only) and at least 1 hour before the game if you want to get inside the Playwright at all! For those non-members or tourists who want a more quiet and seated clasico experience, we can redirect you to nearby bars. Basic Members PLEASE RSVP to have an idea of how many people to expect.

4. The UPPER90 truck, our partners, will be right outside Playwright selling all our Peña goodies (inc. the classic black t-shirts and scarves) as well as other RealMadrid apparel - so leave some time before and during the festivities to pay them a visit.

Hala Madrid, a por ellos!!!

INSTRUCCIONES En Español:


1. Todos los Madridistas están bienvenidos hasta que se llene el bar, la entrada es gratis pero NO se permitirá acceso a banderas/camisetas del Barça. Si su amigo/pariente es del Barça y está interesado en ver el Clásico, puede verlo en el local del Barça (Smithfield-NYC) o en cualquier otro sports bar de NYC.

2. Miembros oficiales de la Peña y SÓLO UN (1) invitado tendrán prioridad de entrada. El area de arriba estará reservada sólo para los miembros oficiales.

3. Turistas, visitantes ocasionales y curiosos serán acomodados en la primera planta del bar, en orden de llegada, y mientras haya espacio. Para este grupo recomendamos que lleguen por lo menos una (1) o dos (2) horas antes del partido si desean sentarse en el la zona del bar. El resto sera standing only. Podremos acomodarles en bares cercanos si desean sentarse con tranquilidad o nuestro bar esta lleno cuando lleguen. Cuanto antes vengan, mejor, no lo dejen para el ultimo minuto.

USA REAL MADRID SUMMER TOUR INFO: Si desean reservar sus tickets para ver el Real Madrid vs Bayern , el 3 de Agosto en el Metlife Stadium de NJ, en la seccion exclusiva de la Penia, pueden hacerlo pagando cash en el segundo piso del Playwright bar. Reserve ya sus tickets. Toda la informacion sobre el evento siga el siguiente link:

http://www.meetup.com/realmadridnyc/events/229899191/


4. UPPER90, nuestros socios, estarán justo afuera de Playwright durante todo el evento vendiendo camisetas y bufandas de nuestra Peña, y también artículos del RealMadrid - se les recomienda los visiten en algún momento durante el evento.

A por ellos, Hala Madrid!!!
