results.description:
March in New York means the St. Patrick's Day parade up 5th Avenue on the 17th and a whole host of events and parties the whole month long. We're going to get into the act ourselves in early April by visiting the Old New York haunts of the famous Irish author and playwright Brendan Behan.

Behan [masked]) was the sensation of the Irish literary world of the 1950s with the publication of his autobiographical novel "Borstal Boy" and plays "The Quare Fellow" and "The Hostage". His works turned the world on to Irish wit and humor while exploring the themes of human freedom and liberation. 

Born and raised in Dublin, Behan loved New York and lived here off and on between 1960 and 1963. To Behan, New York was the "greatest show on earth, for everyone" and "my Lourdes, where I go for spiritual refreshment."

A confirmed alcoholic, Behan also sought liquid refreshment in the pubs and bars of New York. Many of his favorite New York haunts are long gone, but some remain and we are going to visit some of these venues for this meetup.

I'm still working out the full details but here are some places on the itinerary. There will be some walking but that's part of the experience as Behan was famous for wandering around New York and visiting pubs and bars as he went.

Sardi's Restaurant: Sardi's has been a Theater District fixture since the 1920s. Being involved with the New York theater scene, this became one of Behan's New York hangouts. The after-party after the New York premiere of The Hostage was held here and Behan later participated in a roundtable discussion hosted by the New York Times here. Sardi's was also a frequent first stop for Behan and friends before visiting other nightclubs in the city.

Hurley's Saloon: Behan made several appearances on the Jack Paar Show--forerunner to the Tonight Show--when he was in New York. Behan was not good in front of a TV camera, so he would typically loosen himself up with the drink before going on. The chatty, inebriated Behan was a big hit with US TV audiences. Hurley's, an old New York bar dating to 1870, that Rockefeller Center was literally built around, was likely where he went to drink pre-show in those days. The bar even had cue lights to let NBC TV employees know when they had to get back to their shows. Unfortunately, Hurley's lost its lease at its original Rockefeller Center location in 1999. The bar was relocated and re-created a few blocks away on W. 48th Street and is still owned by the same family that last owned the Rockefeller Center location. We will stop here and visit the original location on the walk.


The Cort Theatre: Behan first arrived in New York in September 1960 for the Broadway opening of his play "The Hostage" at the Cort Theatre on West 48th. We'll stop here between bars. We'll also visit the site of the former Monte Rosa restaurant on the same block. This is where Behan fell off the wagon in October 1960.


The Algonquin Hotel: This was Behan's first home in New York in 1960 and '61 and where he conducted his first media interviews. His drunken antics would later get him banned from the hotel. The Algonquin's famed Oak Room is no more, but we can visit the Blue Bar and/or the Lobby Lounge. Behan was infamous for throwing back whiskeys in the latter.

 


The Overlook: Behan was on the wagon when he first arrived in New York, but he loved the Irish pubs of 3rd Avenue and the camaraderie with his fellow Irish they offered. He would visit them regularly even when he was only drinking soda water, staying out 'til all hours of the night in them. The famous literary bar Costello's Saloon at the corner of 3rd and 44th was on his list of places to visit before he even came to New York and would soon become his favorite New York City watering hole. The Costello's that Behan frequented is long gone, but the bar moved half a block away on East 44th before closing about a decade ago. The Overlook now operates out of this space, but it's the closest we can get to the old Costello's.

PJ Clarke's: PJ Clarke's has been a New York classic since the 1880s and it was another of Behan's favorite 3rd Avenue haunts in the early 1960s. It's one of the few bars to survive 3rd Avenue's transformation from gritty, blue-collar residential neighborhood under the 3rd Avenue El to the upscale, skyscraper-dominated area it is today. PJ Clarke's remains one of the best New York bars for celebrity sightings.

PS: Most of the photos on this page were taken during Behan's time in New York.
results.name: New York in Brendan Behan's Footsteps

results.description:
Fun for all ages, the Regatta Playground in West Orange is reportedly amazing!

Here's a brief description -

"Located next to the paddle boat and picnic area in the South Mountain Recreation Complex, the nautical-themed park includes two ships to play on, swings, fossils in climbable cliffs, a dragonfly seesaw, a bouncy bridge, musical instruments and more. One of our favorite parts: Forget uncomfortable park benches, parents can lounge in the colorful Adirondack chairs while they watch the kids play!"

And more from NJ Families -

"Regatta is one of newest playgrounds in the state and already one of our very favorites—nestled in the giant South Mountain Reservation complex right near the Turtle Back Zoo next to the swan-boat-filled Orange reservoir. The play area takes inspiration from its waterside location with an enormous ship centerpiece, complete with huge “rock” outcroppings that make for excellent climbing. There’s a mini boat for toddlers, a dragonfly seesaw, mushroom obstacle courses, cushy surfaces all around to prevent scrapes and plenty of nautical-inspired Adirondack chairs perfect for parent lounging.

Don’t Miss: We love the massive boat structure (named “Lion’s Pride after the Essex County mascot) which features telescopes, climbing walls and slides."

Take a look at some of the pics. Can't wait to see you and your Onlies there!
http://www.njfamily.com/The-Regatta-Playground-in-West-Orange-is-Now-Open/
results.name: Let's Take the Singletons to Regatta Playground

results.description:
Bombay Blues is the winner of the 2015 South Asian Award and long awaited sequel to the critically acclaimed Born Confused. The novel continues the story of Dimple Lala, a young woman whose adventures cut across New York City, London and Bombay. Author and singer/songwriter, Tanuja Desai Hidier, tells a South Asian American coming-of-age story where the dominant beat is blurred transnational spaces and identities, and the prose moves between narrative and poetic. Additionally, the book’s accompanying “booktrack album”, Bombay Spleen, lets the reader explore the story by way of music. Tanuja is considered an innovator of the booktrack where her original songs are based the novel. 

While Tanuja is based in London, we are fortunate to have her join us for the book club meeting and grace us with both her take on her work and the South Asian American scene, which she played a role in developing while living in New York City.

Tanuja will do book signings and make copies of her books and CDs available for purchase. 

________

::Reviews:: via thisistanjua

</a>

<a href="http://thisistanuja.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/10/Tanuja-Desai-Hidier-Bombay-Blues-Cover.jpg">

2015 South Asia Book Award winner Bombay Blues—the long-awaited YA-Adult crossover sequel to Born Confused—sees heroine Dimple Lala journey from New York City to India, and adolescence to adulthood, all the while navigating the border between the traditional and the modern, the self and the other. Her heart and her art.


Set against the backdrop of Mumbai’s contemporary indie music and arts scene, Bombay Blues explores what this new diasporic generation faces today—with a heady mix of uncertainty and determination, despair and inspiration, haunting loss and revelatory love.

“Long awaited, anticipated, likely to be debated: Dimple Lala is back. [Desai] Hidier quietly revolutionized YA literature with Born Confused (2002), and this sequel indicates she’s intent on a repeat… Dense, lyrical, full of neologic portmanteaus and wordplay (“magnifishence”; “candlecadabra”): This is a prose-poem meditation on love, family and homecoming … A journey worth making.”


— Kirkus Reviews, starred review

“Light blue touchpaper and retire: Bombay Blues crackles and burns like a fuse of gunpowder as Tanuja Desai Hidier again takes the coming of age novel to diasporic places it’s never been before.”

— William Dalrymple

“[A] lovingly detailed homage to Bombay… Once again, [Desai] Hidier delivers an immersive blend of introspection, external drama, and lyricism”

— Publishers Weekly

“[Bombay Blues] retains the verve of [Born Confused]; still teeming with energy and music. If once in the past, NRIs were – or thought of themselves as – the “cool ones”, Bombay has its own buzz, with “antiparties”, “Kingfishers at Janata, dubstep at NoSoBoHo, a KFC landmark on Linking Road”…This isn’t the average NRI trawling for an exotic tale, but a discovery that there’s plenty of hipness happening in the Old Country; a chronicle of Bombay cool.”

— Hindustan Times (from “Being Beige” Brunch Magazine feature by Anirudh Bhattacharyya, January 17, 2015)

results.description:
At a family BBQ In 2010, 6 Teens from 2 separate families drowned to death in Louisiana's Red river. There were numerous people standing just feet away, not a single one could swim. The family's comment "None of us could swim, they were yelling, 'Help me, help me. Somebody please help me.' It was nothing I could do but watch them drown, one by one."

That same summer in NYC 7 people drowned to death 4 Adults, 3 children, all of minority descent and all too young.

• 70 Percent of African American Kids & Teens can't swim. (CDC 12')

• If a parent can't swim, there is only a 13% chance that a child in the household will swim. 

• Men are 4 times more likely to drown than women.

• The biggest reason black people give for not learning was hydrophobia "A fear of drowning". I'll let the irrationality of that one sink in.

 Be the change, be the example. Let's burn the Black people don't swim banner!

Argue with the facts all you want it doesn't change them! "I personally hate being a statistic and don't give 2 shits why people including myself can't do something. Just do it I tell myself everything else will fall into place" How about we end the cycle #NotaStatistic #BlackSwim

Black People Love Outdoors & Adventure aka me has been haggling for months and I've secured us all an amazing deal. Here's the scoop! 

5 Package of sessions @ $22 per (1 hr) lesson = $110


Session 1 (Beginner Class & Intermediate Class) - (Pay by Debit or Credit using Venmo to [masked] very easy!)

Saturdays @ 3pm. ST BART'S SWIMMING POOL

• Pack of 5 lessons - 3/19/16; 3/26/16 (No Lesson); 4/2/16; 4/9/16; 4/16/16; 4/23/16

• Sign up now limited spots!

• Great private instructors, Nice & Heated 84 deg pool, changing rooms, close to trains. (Session 2 will progress members)

In 4 short months we have a Surfing Challenge; Kayaking; White water rafting; Swimming/ Beaching, Paddle boarding; Water skiing and an Open water survival techniques class, heck we'll be finding Nemo too. So Get your life!

Spot not confirmed until payment is received.

Note: As an amazing courtesy to our group you will have the chance to make up missed classes. (Please do not abuse this!) 

Let's get wet ;-) ~ Sorry couldn't help myself..blame the Race & Sex comedy show last week.

Recap NYC swim lesson prices: 1. JCC $296 members (~9 Classes), $376 Non-members

2. Nyc Pools Membership cost $75 for 6 months/ $150/ yr. Learn to swim is a lottery System currently session already started and has a very long wait-list.

3. Flushing Meadows Pool Qns - Lottery wait list is 6-8 months long.

4. Vanderbilt YMCA Manh- $140 members (1X/wk for 8 wks), $230 Non-members (1X/wk for 8 wks) Or $235 members (2X/wk for 8 wks), $405 Non-members (2X/wk for 8 wks). Other YMCS's may have different pricing but this gives you an idea.

results.description:
WE WILL BE IN ROOM 608

     Hello everypony and welcome back to the weekly episode screenings! I'm extremely happy to say that these are coming back in full force! And yes you read that description correctly! For Season 4 we watched through a bunch of Gravity Falls episodes, for season 5 we watched through a whole bunch of Steven Universe episodes and now by popular demand we'll be watching through Rick and Morty for season 6!


     For anyone who's never been to one of these screenings, this is how it works. We get together for two hours, I bring the projector and the standing projector screen and set it up in a room that we rent from CAP21. We watch an episode of a cartoon, for this season it's going to be Rick and Morty. It costs five dollars at the door, I wish I could make it free but unfortunately the venue space costs money. The good news is that any extra funds that we get go straight back into bronies NYC. These episode screenings are largely responsible for buying the projector, screen and audio system that we use today so by joining for this event you help contribute to the group, it's a win win!

     After that we watch last week's episode together we move on to the newest episode that came out that day. Once we've watched everything the room shifts over to an artist meetup which will be posted for 5 to 7PM where we can all hang out and draw pictures and stuff from the episode we had just watched. I'll leave a link to that meetup at the bottom of the description.

If you have any questions, comments or concerns feel free to talk about anything you like in the comments down below and the helpful ponies from the group will be more than happy to help you out with anything you need.

WARNING: SPOILERS BELOW

Episode title: The Gift of the Maud Pie

While looking for a location for Rarity's new store in Manehattan, Rarity and Pinkie Pie also search for a gift for Pinkie's sister


Looking forward to seeing you all there! I'm so excited that these are starting up again!
results.name: Weekly Episode Screening #2: Rick and Morty Edition

results.description:
You are invited on Saturday, April 2, 2016 at 3:00 PM to the Masonic Philosophical Society for our next hosted discussion and study. Each month a different topic, ranging from philosophy and science to religion and metaphysics, is discussed and debated. This group, which is open to the public, is where non-members can learn more about Freemasonry, as well as meet local Freemasons.

Study Topic
April's topic will be conducted by Brother Plinio Butten on a study of Freemasonry: How different are the Millennials from Baby Boomers or Generation X? After a short lecture, a discussion and debate by the group will follow.

The Generational boundaries that are constructed from popular and expert consensus is well known to us. From the Baby Boomers to Generation X to Millennials, we are all have a place in the global society of humanity. As the Baby Boomers grow older and pass from this life, we find ourselves beginning to be governed by a technologically-savvy Millennial generation. With such comfort among technology, Baby Boomers and Generation X's find themselves trying to balance their way of being in this fast and ever-changing world. How does one go about this without sacrificing what defines them? How does Freemasonry fit into the tumultuous changes from one generation to the next?

Directions:
[masked]th Ave Whitestone, NY 11357

Mission Statement
The Masonic Philosophical Society embraces the concept of learning, not for school, but for life, and believes that all men, who seek it, deserve access to continued education. We further embrace the concept of a community environment, where ideas can be shared and debated in an open forum. From the seven liberal arts to the arcane, we seek to gain and to share the knowledge that is the legacy of mankind.

More Resources
Website: http://www.philosophicalsociety.org

Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/masonicphilosophicalsociety

Learn more about Freemasonry: http://www.co-masonry.org
results.name: How different are the Millennials from Baby Boomers or Generation X?

results.description:
Alright guys, it looks like spring is upon us. It'd be nice to get another weekend of two of skiing in, but why fight it?  I've decided to change up this favorite of mine a bit.  We'll meet up by the trail head at exit 2 on the Palisades - GPS:[masked], -73.920458.  There's a police station there, as well as bathrooms and a place to fill up water bottles. It's what I've heard referred to as a lollipop loop.  This will made the hike 9 miles on the nose, but what's added is pretty minor elevation changes.  You can also opt to meet us by the Women's Federation Monument around 12:45.  Afterwards, we'll probably stop at the Market on 9w, because we'll be hungry and it's awesome.  Anyway, here are the details:

This is the building near the trail head.  Parking is across the street.

The Giant Stairs Area: State Line Length: 9 mi. (includes steep descent, mile-long rock scramble, and a steep climb) Time: 4+ hrs. Map: Map 3 Parking: State Line Lookout Bus Access: See "Point Lookout" hike description on our "Public Transportation" page This is the "hike of hikes" on the Palisades, and we really recommend trying something a little easier first ... the "Stairs" are as much rock scramble as hike, with a very steep ascent at the end—never attempt this hike when it’s wet or icy out! Begin this loop hike at Lookout Inn at State Line Lookout. From here, you can begin by going either south or north. To begin south: Begin at Lookout Inn and go to the ski trail entrance at the northwest corner of the parking area. At your first left, take ski trail "A" which also overlaps with the aqua-blazed Long Path. Follow until it comes to a junction, where you turn left to cross the entrance road to State Line Lookout (use caution here). Continue through the gap in the parapet stones and into the woods. The trail goes down a ravine on stone steps.

This is the Women's Federation Monument, where we'll meet up with anyone who wants to opt for the shorter version.

At the base of the ravine, the aqua Long Path crosses a wooden bridge and then intersects the blue-and-white-blazed Forest View Trail; here you will turn left (east) on the Forest View Trail, taking it down to the river, where it will end at the white-blazed Shore Trail (this descent is very steep). Take the white Shore Trail north about 0.25 mi. to the beginning of the Giant Stairs, a formation created by thousands of rock slides over the eons.

You’ll scramble over the rocks for about 1 mi., following the white blazes all the way (some of these, you’ll notice, are in the shape of half-moons—don’t let this throw you). The Shore Trail finally levels off along the river, and goes to Peanut Leap Cascade. 


After a steep ascent on the white Shore Trail, turn left (south) on the aqua-blazed Long Path, cross the stream, and follow the Long Path back to start. To begin north: Head north along Old Route 9W, noting the aqua blazes of the Long Path along the way—you’ll be following these markers for the first part of this hike. About 100 yd. along, the Long Path leaves the old cement road and goes into the woods, more or less following the cliff edge (and for a while overlapping Ski Trail E). About 1 mi. along, you come to the State Line Monument and a chain link fence; here the trail jogs right (east) to go around the fence, and begins to descend a series of stone steps, with excellent vistas north toward the Tappan Zee. At the base of the steps, the trail jogs to the left, to bear northwest for a time and so headed away from the river. In less than 0.5 mi., you’ll cross a stream on wooden bridges. Across this stream, turn right (east), at the start of the white-blazed Shore Trail that follows the stream toward the river. Just before the river, this trail gets quite steep and is prone to erosion—use caution. You will arrive at river level at the base of Peanut Leap Cascade. Continue on the white-blazed Shore Trail as it heads south along the Hudson, then follow it over the Giant Stairs, finally to the trailhead of the blue-and-white-blazed Forest View Trail. This will lead you steeply back up to the aqua-blazed Long Path. Here, turn right (north), cross the bridge, still going up, and follow the Long Path back to the starting point. http://www.njpalisades.org/hikesChallenging.html#giantStairs and here's the pdf map from that site: http://www.njpalisades.org/pdfs/mapGrayscale.pdf
results.how_to_find_us: I'll be by the trail head at noon o'clock
results.name: Noon O'Clock Hiking Series: State Line Lookout

Join us for figure drawing session in Ukrainian Village.


This meetup is open to sketchers of all levels. 

Why are we different? 


• Large, well lit, and quiet space on a second floor of a secure building (with elevator). 

•[masked] minute poses. Model takes a break every 20 min.

• Latecomers are ok.

• Mingle, look at each other's work during the break and get inspired. Nobody will judge you. All levels and drawing styles are welcome and your artistry is appreciated.

How it works?

• We draw for 3 hours from a live (nude) model.  

• We warm up with 5 minute poses and work all the way up to 20 minute poses by the end. Model takes 5 minute break every 20 minutes. 

• There are seats for everyone at the tables. 

• Access to a sink is available for watercolor artist.

• BYOM - Bring your own materials (no oil or acrylic paint or sprays).

Entrance to our building:

If you have any questions please feel free to email me. I'm looking forward to meeting you there. 


Phillip

results.description:
This meeting is for both fiction and non-fiction writers. Depending on how many people sign up to come and to share their work at this meeting, we will divide the group into two tables. A "fiction writers" table and a "non-fiction writers" table.

Bring a piece to read and discuss, up to 1500 words, or simply bring yourself. If you bring a piece, please make copies for the others. How many copies? Check here the last day and you will find the answer.

All formats welcome: poems, short stories, flash fiction, novellas, novels, articles, blog entries, essays, children books, screen and theatrical plays, etc.


Here is how we will divide the tables if needed:

1) Fiction writers: Genres covered are literary/upscale/art fiction, poetry, all kinds of mysteries, speculative fiction (fantasy, urban fantasy, horror and sci-fi), chick lit, women fiction, romance (all kinds, including historical, regent, sexy and erotica), western.


2) Non-fiction writers: Genres covered are all kids of non-fiction, autobiographies and memoires, academic non-fiction, news articles, blogs, poetry, non-fiction screenplays etc.
results.name: Hudson Writers Meeting

venue.name: Washington Square Park

results.description:
Have you ever just looked at a person and thought to yourself, "I'd love to smack him with a pillow?" Well, if you haven't, you certainly will at the gargantuan pillow fight that takes place in NYC every year. What am I talking about? I'm talking about NYC's 11th Annual Pillow Fight- an event so awesome it grew to what is now also the 9th Annual Pillow Fight Day (we're talking global Pillow Fight Day, here).

I've done this a couple times before- check out some pictures from last year here. I've been waiting with barely contained patience for this year's opportunity to wreak havoc with a bundle of downy softness. And of course, I want all of you to share that opportunity with me. So if you'd like to strike from on high with pillowy wrath, come and join us for this absolutely guaranteed to be fun event.

Just a couple things to keep in mind:

+ Soft, feather-free pillows only!
+ Swing lightly, many people will be swinging at once.
+ Do not swing at people without pillows or with cameras.
+ Remove glasses beforehand!
+ Deposit pillows in donation boxes or take them with you.
+ Pajamas welcome.

Not only is this an opportunity for great fun, but also a chance for good works. Last year Pillow Fight folks donated over 1500 pillows to homeless shelters in Brooklyn and the Bronx. So you might consider donaating your pillow this year.

Newmindspace also does a great job of cleaning up the park each year after all the fun has been had. If you're interested in volunteering for the cleanup crew, email [masked]

We'll be meeting on the Southeast corner of Fifth Ave and 8th Street, just one block from Washington Square Park. From there, we'll walk and then wreak a havoc wrought of pillows.
results.name: Pillow Fight NYC 2016

results.description:
This is an open house and introduction to Teaneck Meditation. This introduction gives hope for those seeking happiness, peace, and truth. At Teaneck Meditation we use a very simple, yet direct way of cleansing and freeing the mind. This meditation is a customized guided one-on-one practice through self-reflection. Give your mind and heart a break from the chaos of everyday life! Deeply examine and empty your self to find absolute peace and freedom! If you are interested in becoming a member of our meditation center we will offer a special discounted price for meetup members only! 

We are located at 475 Cedar Lane Teaneck, NJ 07666. Our meditation center is located next to Veggie Heaven. Metered parking is in the front, and additional free parking is located in the back of the shopping strip. This introduction will last about an hour to an hour and a half. If you have many plans for the day please say this before the meetup starts so we can accomodate you properly. 

**If you are not able to attend this event, but have an interest in Teaneck Meditation you can call our center to have a personal introduction today! Teaneck Meditation is a non-profit organization and is tax deductible. A $10 donation is appreciated for the introduction. 

* 


475 Cedar Lane Teaneck, NJ 07666

results.description:
Please read carefully: This event is being hosted by Dave Cervini's newyorksocialnetwork.com and several of their partner Meet Up groups.  The number of people you see registered on your Meet Up represent only a portion of those actually attending. If you have any questions or want to know how many are attending from all groups please contact the event host at [masked].

</a>If you are a novice or love art, our Chelsea Art Gallery Tours are a fun and casual way to explore a great part of the city while socializing and making new friends and connections.

With over 300 art galleries in Chelsea, our Gallery Tour  Led by Rafael Risemberg with a Ph.D. in arts education  finds the most innovative art, and leads you on an insightful, entertaining and affordable journey through the contemporary art scene.  Rafael explains the art in ways that makes the experience meaningful to those who don’t know a lot about art as well as those who do.

Our tours take place RAIN, Snow or SHINE, as we’re indoors over 90% of the time. You will be amazed at how much you will learn and enjoy both the art and the people on the tour!

The group will meet at a local cafe prior to the tour.  Following the tour many from the group stay together for a drink or a bite to eat.

Pay $25 when you arrive

DO NOT REGISTER FOR THIS EVENT UNLESS YOU WILL ACTUALLY ATTEND.

Can I come alone?  Yes 99% of the people come to this event on their own to meet new people and check out some cool art.

What do I wear? Dress for the weather.  Be casual and comfortable.

What to expect: We are piggy backing on a larger tour.   We will have 10-15 from our group.  The age range for our people is 20's -40's ( the larger group is 20's - 60's)

How long does it last? about 2 hours

How do I know who is leading the group? We meet separate from the main tour at a local cafe.  Our tour host will have a sign at the bar and you will have a chance to have something to eat or drink before we start the tour.  If you are not hungry just socialize.  When we are finished we walk over together to join the main tour. 

If there does not seem to be a lot of people registered on this Meet Up, are there more people going?

Yes as explained, this event is being promoted by several Meet Up groups and

<a href="http://www.newyorksocialnetwork.com/">www.newyorksocialnetwork.com

.  If you only see a few on your Meet Up don’t worry you won’t be alone!  If you want to know exact numbers or have any questions you can contact the event organizer directly at [masked] or call[masked]
results.name: NY's #1 Chelsea Art Gallery Best Exhibits Guided Tour: Socialize and Explore!

results.description:
Looking to transition soon from meetup so follow and join our facebook page for updates on the group, art relating to the theme, and more at https://www.facebook.com/groups/ImaginativeIllustratorsNYC/ 

Today we will be focused and immersive in a specific theme we will work on together as a group. Conceptual Challenges are pretty much the same as our Lets Draw Togethers but are more specific and maybe more challenging conceptually. 

In today's challenge in light of the spring bloom soon to come we will be drawing our own fantastical floral character. By this I mean drawing such things as faeries, nymphs, elementals, creatures, and etc influenced by and that incoporate any plantlife and flowers.

The meetup will be split into three parts: First a half hour of warm-up drawings followed by a break of conceptual discussion, then after an hour and a half drawing your chosen idea and design, lastly we'll discuss each others fully developed drawings and ideas as a group.

So don't forget to bring your supplies and sketchbook as this meetup is going to be drawing focused! Also feel free to bring any reference material that will help out with the theme in addition to what will be provided.

You can find me at the tables on the second floor of the Cranberry Cafe.

I hope to see you there and having fun participating in this new style of meetup and exercising, challenging, or developing your drawing and conceptual skills with other imaginative artists throughout NYC. Any skill level and any style is welcomed!
results.name: Conceptual Challenge! Theme: A Floral Fantasy

results.description: Lurie Daniel Favors is an attorney and the author of Afro State of Mind: Memories of a Nappy Headed Black Girl©. This book traces Lurie’s journey—from the hot comb, the Jheri curl, the perm and the Big Chop, all the way through her life as all-natural attorney defending high-profile cases in a racist court system. As she examines the history behind nappiness, Lurie learns that Black hair, identity and skin color are international cultural experiences—with personal and political power. For More Information Click Here.
results.name: Lurie Favors at Sisters Uptown Bookstore

results.description:
Please buy your tickets for the 4:50pm show beforehand as it will likely sell out.

From the Film Forum website:

FRANCOFONIA, directed by master Russian filmmaker Alexander Sokurov (RUSSIAN ARK), is an urgent meditation on the essential relationship between art, culture, and 20th century European history, set in occupied Paris c.1940. Applying his uniquely personal vision, Sokurov paints a fascinating portrait of two real-life characters: the Louvre’s wartime director, Jacques Jaujard, and Count Franziskus Wolff-Metternich, the Nazis’ emissary to the great museum. The movie is a battle of wits between these remarkable art professionals – enemies, then collaborators – whose unlikely alliance becomes the driving force behind the preservation of one of the world’s great artistic treasure troves. A playful subplot introduces the ghosts of Napoleon and Marianne, France’s symbol of liberté, égalité, fraternité.


Buy tickets here:
http://filmforum.org/film/francofonia-film

Trailer:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=yGF7vZALBQU
results.name: "FRANCOFONIA"­ Saturday April 2nd, 4:50pm show at the Film Forum in NYC

For 50% off tickets; buy  tickets online until Friday, 4/1/16, 11:59PM. After deadline, $20 at door.

 There will be drink specials  and free appetizers.


21 yrs and older with valid ID***

We will be celebrating White Day with a twist - White Day for youth: Celebrating love and mentoring. Sign up to be a mentor to a Korea youth at the event.

For half off of ticket prices please go to http://intimacysolutions.org/product/mentoroutreach/ to pay online. $10

There are 20 Korean youth that have been waiting for a mentor for over 2 years! Let's fill the void. Sign up today!

Also, learn about how you can be a mentor for Chinese, Vietnamese and other Asian youth.

 Hosted by Intimacy solutions in partnership with Big Brothers & Big Sisters NYC and NYC/NJ Korean Meetup Social group. Staff from Big Brothers and Big Sisters will be on site to discuss their Asian mentoring program and to sign you up. No commitment to be a mentor however to attend.

Also, Fellas, show ladies some love by buying them a drink. Ladies please accept drinks from guys since it is White Day!

Traditionally, White Day is Korea's Valentine's Day where men show love to their women by giving women sweets in March. We, however, in Partnership with Big Brothers and Big Sisters of NYC,  are planning a happy hour and social networking event at a rooftop in Manhattan in April. The event will be going towards a good cause: to locate Korean mentors for 20 Korean youth

There will me a small cover fee since we are reserving the entire venue and for charitable cause.

$10 advanced RSVP - RSVP on Meetup and pay ticket online only   to get discounted rate.

Buy Ticket at Buy tickets at www.intimacysolutions.org

                                           or

$20 at the door entrance

Dress Code: Fun, Dressy, or Business Casual. No sneakers or caps

  There will be drink specials  and free appetizers.

You don't have to be Korean or Asian to attend but an ally or in solidarity with the cause.

Bring your business cards too, to network and meet new, great people!

Please RSVP if interested.

Located in the heart of downtown Manhattan, prepare yourself for a breath-taking panoramic view of New York City.  With a direct view of the Empire State Building. Rooftop93 will be a night to remember and an avenue to ring in the Spring!

http://rooftop93.com/

results.description:
A Conversation About Happiness

Alternating Hosts: George & Michael Y

</a> CitiCorp Atrium Lower Level
153 E 53rd street (Between Lexington and 3rd ave)

Look for our red Meetup Sign.

Get ready to get happier simply by talking about happiness! The theory behind these events comes from a classic psychology study showing that by simply talking regularly about happiness we can become much happier.

While we'll depart from them however much we may wish, like by talking about gratitude, acts of kindness, meditation and other happiness techniques, the following list of 14 topics will serve as a backdrop for our discussions.

1. Keep busy and be more active
2. Spend more time socializing
3. Be productive at meaningful work
4. Get better organized and plan things out
5. Stop worrying
6. Lower your expectations and aspirations
7. Develop positive, optimistic thinking
8. Become present oriented
9. Develop an outgoing, social personality
10. Work on a healthy personality
11. Be yourself
12. Eliminate negative feelings and problems
13. Close relationships are the number one source of happiness
14. Put happiness as your most important priority.

Here's some background on the research our group is based on.

In 1980 three New Zealand researchers found that after eight 2-hour conversation sessions about happiness over four weeks, their subjects reported a 22 percent increase in their happiness. Continuing their twice-weekly sessions, by the sixteenth week they reported being 42 percent happier.

Our list of topics comes from Fort Myers, Florida psychologist Michael Fordyce's "14 Fundamentals of Happiness." In 1977, Fordyce pioneered the science of happiness-increase with the world's first experiment designed to boost individual happiness.

That's the group. It's important that our events be fun! So with that in mind, let's get serious about ramping up our enjoyment of life!

(photo of atrium and location of meetup table)

(photo of atrium entrance at the corner of 53rd and Lex.)


At the NE corner of 53rd and Lex., walk down wide steps (see photo) leading to lower outdoor patio. Pass entrance to the subway station on the right, and walk through the revolving door. Walk straight about 30 yards, down a few steps; the Atrium is on the left.

Resources:

For those interested in learning about the major findings from social science research about happiness, and becoming happier, here are links to several excellent peer-reviewed articles that can be downloaded as pdf files for free. (Note: Although these classic articles are somewhat dated, decades of research on happiness reveal that findings on happiness tend to be extremely stable over time.)

<a href="http://citeseerx.ist.psu.edu/viewdoc/download?doi=10.1.1.335.9655&rep=rep1&type=pdf">Pursuing Happiness: The Architecture of Sustainable Change
By S Lyubomirsky, KM Sheldon and D Schkade, 2005.  21 pages

In Pursuit of Happiness: Empirical Answers to Philosophical Questions
By P Kesebir and E Diener, 2008. 9 pages.

Subjective Well-Being: Three Decades of Progress
By E Diener, EM Suh, RE Lucas and HL Smith, 1999. 27 pages

results.description:
Welcome!

If you love to play basketball, but height is not your advantage, come out and play with people who aren't excessively tall! In the tradition of Spud Webb, anyone under 5'8", male or female, is welcome to join us on the court. We'll get some teams together and play some competitive, but relaxed bball-- and without any giant hands in our faces! :-p

We rent out the gym from 5:00-8:00pm. Please arrive at least 5-10 minutes early as the sooner everyone arrives, the sooner we can begin playing. Note that all games stop at 7:45pm as we must be out of the gym no later than 8:00pm. (If you get there late, please only ring the bell once. It is very loud! And it takes us a few minutes to get downstairs.) The gym is on the 10th fl. & has adjoining bathrooms, lockers, and water fountains.

Don't forget:


* You must be no more than 5'8" to play!

* You must RSVP on the site in order to attend!

* To be eligible to play we ask that you sign an annual waiver, which can be found here.


* If you have any problems with the prepay, just shoot one of the organizers a message. 

The Rules:

1. Play by ones and twos to 11 - win by one point.

2. Make it - take it.

3. Backcourt if the ball hits the rim or backboard. Air balls are fair game to put right back up.

4. Jump balls/disputed calls will be determined by a three pointer since the laws of basketball physics are very clear that "the ball never lies."

5. Walls, half-court line, and ceiling are out of bounds. 

6. Usually each team has 1-2 subs. Subs should enter mid-game (one of the teams reaches 6 points) and should start the following game. Teams can regulate themselves but let's just make sure everyone plays!

See you on the court! B-)

***SPECIAL NOTES***

Please do not show up unannounced (without RSVP):

This gym is small and 22 is the maximum number of players we can realistically allow. There is a waiting list if all spots have been taken. If you do show up unannounced we will have to ask you to leave. 

Refund Policy:

A refund/credit is available if you change your RSVP at least 24 hours in advance OR, if you change your RSVP within 24 hours, as long as you post a comment on the event page and someone picks up your spot (BOTH are required).

Lastly...

Feel free to bring your own basketball for shoot-around. And don't forget to clip your fingernails prior to game day. We tried playing with Edward Scissorhands once - it didn't turn out so well.

The Afterparty: 

We'll hit up McSwiggans (393 2nd Avenue @ 23rd St) later!

results.description:
The first Saturday of every month we meet at 5 pm, instead of the normal weekly Saturday meeting time of 2 pm.

After our meditation program, which ends by 7 pm, we enjoy a healthy potluck dinner.  Please join us!  It's really a great way for us to get to know each other better. 

Log onto www.perfectpotluck.com to let us know what you'd like to bring. Type in Administrator: Fitzpatrick, password: Ananda. You can see what others are bringing to help you decide! Call Linda Fitzpatrick at[masked] if you have any questions or need help entering your food selection on the perfectpotluck.com site.

The potluck goes on until about 9 pm; although you can leave anytime you like.  It's all very informal and friendly.

We meet at the Wilson House of the First Baptist Church, 456 North Street (corner of Bryant Ave.) in White Plains. Email Merrill Harmin, [masked] if you have questions.

Our typical agenda:

- We orient new visitors and then chat a bit, as by sharing what's new or good in our lives.
- Then we meditate together chanting mantra followed by the beautiful sounds of a gong.
- And finally we share thoughts and questions, learning something new sometimes, generally supporting each other best we can.

The group has been meeting for some time before Meetup began. The Meetup page is not a reflection of the group's attendance as it shows only the Meetup members that are planning to attend a particular meeting. The special potluck meeting we hold the first Saturday of each month has an average attendance of about two dozen members.
results.name: American Meditation Society  - Monthly Meditation and Potluck Dinner

results.description:
Join us for Target First Saturdays and enjoy engaging and eclectic free art and entertainment every month (except September), 5 to 11 p.m. BKM Café offers artist-created sandwiches, as well as salads, sweets, and a variety of beverages. Parking is a flat rate of $6 starting at 5 p.m. (All other Saturdays, we close at 6 p.m.)

Some Target First Saturday programs take place in smaller and more intimate locations, so you’ll need a ticket. Lines often form 30 minutes before ticket distribution at the Admissions Desk. Members can pick up tickets from the Membership Desk while supplies last. While we do our best to keep listings as up-to-date as possible, sometimes last-minute program changes are unavoidable.

April:

Falu returns to the Museum to enchant with her fusion of Hindustani classical, raga, pop, and jazz.

Planetary (Guy Reid, 2015, 52 min.) explores humanity's cosmic origins and invites us to rethink our relationship to each other and the world around us. Followed by a talkback. Free tickets (310) at the Admissions Desk at 5 p.m.

Create scrolls and paint papier-mâché beads with artists Steven and William Ladd, to contribute to a community mural project in City Point, Brooklyn. Free tickets (165) at the Admissions Desk at 5 p.m.

Enjoy ten-minute discussions about art related to nature and agriculture.

High-energy band Brown Rice Family combines reggae, hip-hop, dancehall, Brazilian, Afro-beat, jazz styling, Latin, and funk.

Dust off your dancing shoes with a performance and workshop by Earl Mosley's Diversity of Dance, presented by the Brooklyn Dance Festival.

BaddDDD Sonia Sanchez (Barbara Attie, Janet Goldwater, and Sabrina Schmidt Gordon, 2015, 91 min.) reflects on the life and impact of poet, teacher, and activist Sonia Sanchez. Followed by a talk back with Gordon and poet Ursula Rucker. Free tickets (310) at the Admissions Desk at 7 p.m.

Desiree Bailey performs a deep-sea poetic exploration of mermaids, black female divinity, and the Haitian Revolution. Laura Lamb Brown uses poetry, song, and Craigslist posts to tell a story of love between a seal-woman and a farmer in Rhode Island. Free tickets (25) at the Admissions Desk at 7:30 p.m.

WNYC's Death, Sex & Money podcast hosts a dance break featuring a listener-powered playlist of "anthems of change."

Audiences worldwide have been inspired by Maya Azucena’s powerful voice and equally stirring messages of social activism since her performance here in 2012. Now she’s back to put some Spring in our step and get our hearts beating for the new season!

https://www.brooklynmuseum.org/visit/first_saturdays
results.name: Brooklyn Museum Target First Saturday

results.description:
How to be unconditionally happy?

A mind that is calm, without anticipation and agitation is the birth right of all individuals. A mind that is in the present moment will be happy.


What can get you to that state?

The rest you gain by reposing in yourself is deeper than the deepest sleep. The deeper your rest, the more dynamic your activity is. By being peaceful and happy you can turn your body into a power-house by generating an inner source of energy.


Meditation is simple and is a practical way to recharge and rejuvenate; empowering you to do more of the things you love.

Come join us for free guided session and experience the power of meditation.


Workshop Contents:

- Understanding the nature of the mind!
- Relaxing Breathing Techniques
- Guided Meditation
- Introduction to the Happiness Course and Sudarshan Kriya

results.name: Yogic Breathing & Meditation for Deep Stress Relief

results.description:
This Meetup is basically to raise the awareness of Discord through other available applications while connecting Bronies-NYC together more efficiently. [Communication is important!] 


Discord provides a unique, high quality and flexible text/voice chat system among-st its users, it has many simple features.

Discussions Page Info: [Basically all possible needed info covered in a simple explanation + color coded.] http://www.meetup.com/Bronies-NYC/messages/boards/thread/49406195


From my experience since launch at Thanksgiving Monthly Meetup,Discord itself is becoming the "Discussions" page located on top. It is very unnoticeable page but even with few members on Discord, we've made good conversations and progressive chats about topics we would very much to see, similar to folks who do post on the "Discussions" page. 
[That's a plus! Thanks to communication! Bronies Unite!]

We already have decent amount of people within the Discord server so feel free to hop in and pop a chatter or two and anyone can join in! [Including meeting plenty of the Admins/Organizers!]

For more beneficial reasons, I've created a Bronies-NYC Introduction Server so folks can be more familiar with Discord as well as the purpose of the various Text or Voice Channels provided among its Members!

After you're done reading or learning about the various Channels provided, a Alicorn (Admin) or Maud (Moderator), will then directly message you a Server link to the actual Bronies-NYC Server where we all get to hang out and have fun as well... but Online!


Bronies-NYC Discord Introduction Server: https://discord.gg/0u...­ 

[You can join as anonymous if clicking the link through browser otherwise you have to sign up, and copy the link and join through the installed program on computer/phone.] 

The time set for Meetup just when most folks are online or active, Discord is continuous.

_____________________________________________

Update: Didn't realize a new episode of MLP would come out so soon, how awkward of me! xP

But because of the various livestreams and online Text/Voice Channel we provide on Discord, those going to watch the screening on release time. I was hoping we could be online, Discord, to chat or watch it together then afterwards just talk about it!
In #spoilerific-episode-discussion

Reminder: Not everyone is able to see the episode right away so the use of this Text Channel would be highly appreciated!

Including if you're attending Weekly Episode screening, there's a no spoiler rule, so keep it to yourself if you're there! :D

Following are possible livestream links:


HaxMega: 
[ http://www.ustream.tv/channel/hax-mega-s-mlp-fim-season-2-countdown ] 
BronyState: 
[ http://www.bronystate.net/theater/ ] 
BronyNetwork: 
[ http://original.livestream.com/thebronynetwork7 ] 
MLP-Episodes.tk: 
[ http://mlp-episodes.tk/livestream.html ] 

(I don't know any other good streaming sites, comment below if you know any!)

results.description:
****READ THIS FIRST || Parade Grounds Game Standards ****


Meet on field 8!!!

The game is scheduled to start at 5:00. We typically start 15 minutes after 5:00. Your RSVP is good if you come on time. If you come after teams are divided then you run the risk of not playing. Those who have RSVP’ed get first preference to play (This does not apply to anyone on the waiting list). Also, please  Un-RSVP if you will not be attending. That gives other people a chance to play.

Rules and guidelines:

These games are geared towards advanced to intermediate players.

Teams are divided by two team captains (captains pick players in turns in an attempt to keep teams balanced and competitive)

Physical play is allowed as long as it isn't overly aggressive or dirty.

Slide tackles are allowed only to block a shot on goal or to intercept a pass  NO slide tackling on a player with the ball.

Ball hogging is absolutely not tolerated

Keep in mind as we don't have permit, we need to be flexible.

results.description: The heroes judiciously retreated in the face of inspired battle tactics from the foes: rats in the first wave, burrowing elementals from underground, archers behind cover and a mysterious armored orc spell caster who never attacked directly but guided the flow of combat. The Knights in Silver were pleased with the intelligence gathered about the enemies organization and likely tactics, but nonetheless troubling questions were raised. Who trained the orcs? Why did the vulture demon watch and hold back? How did such a large garrison infiltrate so close to Silverymoon? And what evil mastermind is behind all of this? During the retreat the party befriended a Xorn, which may motivate future exploration. Indeed word of the parties bravery has started to spread and the elf Mirabel attempted to hire the party to locate her missing son Farlien in the Savage Frontier region to the far South of the Silver Marches. The next adventure begins at the Dancing Goat as the heroes enjoy a well deserved rest and attempt to make sense of recent events.

results.description:
Chanting is used ancient cultures all over the world as a way of celebration.  The chanting that we do on Bhakti Nite is based in Sanskrit chants, which have a vibrational effect on the heart and mind.  If you enjoy music, meditation or just meeting new people come try it out.  The chants are simple and are repeated over and over so that anyone can join in, no knowledge of Sanskrit is necessary.

Cost: None, donations are happily accepted.

Bring yourself and a friend if you wish!

group.name: "Art of Living" NYC- Making Life a Celebration

results.description:
During weekly meetings on Saturday evenings in the East Village of New York City, Atmanivedana das (Atma) and Subhangada devi dasi (Subhie) teach how to hear and chant sanskrit names for God in kirtan and teach a systematic study the Bhagavad-gita As It Is.  Kirtan meditation consists of hearing and chanting sanksrit names for God to the accompaniment of melodious and rhythmic music in order to invoke God's divine mercy and presence.  Bhagavad-gita As It Is is studied according to the ancient, yet unbroken, chain of teachers, as taught originally by Krishna and eventually Sri Caitanya Mahaprabhu, Rupa Goswami, and more recently A.C. Bhaktivedanta Swami Prabhupada, the Founder-Acarya of the International Society for Krishna Consciousness.   

Our focus is a systematic and thematic, but not difficult to understand, study of the Bhagavad-gita As It Is.  Everyone will read verses together from the Bhagavad-gita, copies of which will be provided for attendees to reference during the meetup.  Atma and Subhie will together explain the Bhagavad-gita verses according to the ancient tradition that they have studied and lived by for almost fifty-five years, combined.  We will learn about various fascinating topics, such as karma, reincarnation, the soul, the material energy, the Supreme Soul, time, and the relationship between the soul, the material energy, and the Supreme Soul.

Hard cover copies of the beautiful Bhagavad-gita As It Is with the original 700 sanskrit verses, translations, and elaborate purports by A.C. Bhaktivedanta Swami Prabhupada, will be available for any member who might choose to take one home for a suggested donation of $10.

This meetup is intended for everyone who is interested without discrimination and regardless of one's familiarity with the subject matter.  Please come and relish this most wonderful discussion and kirtan, celebrating the glories of bhakti yoga, i.e., devotional service to God, who is known according to the Bhagavad-gita by the name Krishna.

Here is the general schedule of our meetups: we begin the evening with a kirtan that lasts about half an hour -- until about 6:00 p.m.  Then, we have a class on Bhagavad-gita As It Is, which lasts for about an hour and a half.  In the class, we will go through verses of the Gita in order, continuing from where the last class left off, with questions pertaining to those verses being encouraged throughout the class.  By about 7:30, the last kirtan begins; it lasts for about 30 minutes.  A sumptuous and nutritious vegetarian dinner is served after that.

Admission to each meetup is free.  Donations for the meetup's expenses are welcome, but not at all required!

Atma is an initiated priest who since 1990 has been studying, teaching, and living according to the teachings of the Bhagavad-gita as taught and followed by A.C. Bhaktivedanta Swami Prabhupada. After living in a monastic setting for eight years, Atma resumed his undergraduate education at Brown University, where he hosted weekly programs that focused on kirtan and Bhagavad-gita.  He then enrolled at the University of Chicago Law School from which he graduated in 2004 and from which he received a merit scholarship.  Atma practices law in courts throughout the country, with his office in Long Island, and his concentration in securities and derivative litigation.  His primary goal is to imbibe in his own life the devotional teachings of the Bhagavad-gita and to share the same with others as a humble offering to God.

Subhie has been living her life according to the teachings of the Bhagavad-gita since 1991 and is also an initiated priest.  Subhie lived in a monastic setting until 2005.   From 1991 to 2005, Subhie taught Bhagavad-gita in Croatia, Serbia, Greece, Germany, and United Kingdom.  Subhie spent several years studying Vedic knowledge in India, primarily in the holy town, Vrindavana.  After 2005, Subhie resumed her undergraduate education in religion at the University of London -- and then locally at Queens College, after she moved to New York and married Atma.  Subhie completed her Master's degree in teaching at Queens College and is a school teacher.

results.description:
The Poem

I was originally planning to inflict Paradise Lost on the group, but for reasons Donald Sutherland can explain far better than I (which is so often the case), I've decided to go with Allen Ginsberg's Howl, a timeless classic that dares to ask just how strong is peyote?

The Other Poems

To add spice to the evening (and so I don't have to bother editing the title of this particular meetup), we're also inviting everyone to bring and share with the group a favorite poem. You don't have to, of course, but if you do you'll be asked to read it aloud for everyone--with as much or as little performance enthusiasm as you wish. I will impose no limit on length, so if you are super disappointed I passed over Milton, bring it in and we'll all go out for Sunday brunch when you finish.

The Whiskey

Red Breast 12 

A  Pure Pot Still Irish whiskey, Redbreast is well known for its nutty and rich notes with a spicy and good bodied palate...a fitting tribute for Ginsberg's Howl. 


The Venue

White Horse Tavern, established in 1880 is a certified Poetry Landmark by the Academy of American Poets. 


**Please note that this is a CASH ONLY venue.**

results.description:
Come join us for our inaugural Circling night at Bhakti Barn in Glen Ridge, NJ. Newcomers and those experienced in the practice are both welcome!

Fee: $20 registration; $25 cash at the door
Register here: http://www.meetup.com/New-Jersey-Circling-Authentic-Relating/events/229751159/
If you don't have a Meetup account, just send $20 via PayPal to [masked] and specify in the message which Circling event you're registering for.

What is Circling?

Simply put, Circling is a relating practice where participants explore and express what it's like to be with each other in the present-moment. We don't try to change what's happening in the moment, but we certainly welcome expressions of our desires to do so. It is typically practiced in groups and can focus on relationship with one person the whole time or relationships with many people at indiscriminate times.

Why do we do it?

There's something about present-moment relationship with other human beings that helps us to gain more insight into ourselves and each other. That, and such quality attention and connection is nourishing unto itself. If you value intimacy in your relationships and/or seeing aspects of yourself that you're not yet aware of, this practice is for you.

I'm still not entirely clear on what I'd be getting myself into if I participated, can you tell me more?

I'm happy to answer any questions you may have about the practice, and you can message me or email me at [masked]. That being said, I fully encourage you to give it a try for yourself and see if it's something you enjoy. We certainly respect everyone's sovereignty and hold no obligations for you to stay for any longer than you'd like to.

For more information on Circling, visit any of the following pages: 
http://integralcenter.org/what-is-circling/ 
http://circlinginstitute.com/circling/what-is-circling/ 
http://circlingeurope.com/about/
results.name: Circling Night in Glen Ridge

results.description:
Join us for a Cuddle Party - an experiential workshop and social event.  Where else can you attend a workshop in your pajamas, or yoga clothes.

To attend you must purchase a ticket in advance. See details below.


Cuddle Party is … a workshop!

Though touch is natural, the skills that make it welcome and enjoyable have to be learned. Skills of communication, boundaries, asking for what you want, and saying ‘Yes’ or ‘No’ with clarity and kindness.

Cuddle Party is led by trained and certified Cuddle Party Facilitators. The Facilitator’s job is to guide you into those skills gently and easily, in a fun, safe and light hearted way. We welcome you and create an atmosphere of respect, and remain available for questions and support.

At a Cuddle Party you gain:
* Clarity and confidence
* Boundary and communication skills
* Comfort, support and encouragement
* The secrets to welcome, relaxed, non-sexual touch

The skills you learn at Cuddle Party translate into every day life, right from the start. When boundaries and consent are clear, every relationship is easier.

Where else can you attend a workshop in your pajamas?

Cuddle Party is … a social event!


We open with a Welcome Circle - about 45 minutes of introductions, rules and a few games to help everyone get comfortable. We teach communication and boundary skills in ways that are lighthearted and fun.

Then we open up for ‘free-style’ cuddling. You have plenty of time to relax, chat, share a back rub or other welcome touch, cuddle, have a snack or just hang out.

You can come to a Cuddle Party to meet new people, to enjoy amazing conversations, to touch, to be touched, to have fun, to practice asking for what you want, to practice saying “no” to what you don’t want — all in a setting structured to be a safe place for exploration and enjoyment. Shucks, you can even come to a Cuddle Party just to cuddle!

These are the Cuddle Party rules.

1) Pajamas (or cuddle-clothes) stay on the whole time.

2) You don't have to cuddle anyone at a Cuddle Party, ever.

3) You must ask permission and receive a verbal YES before you touch anyone. (Be as specific in your request as you can.)

4) If you're a yes, say YES. If you're a no, say NO.

5) If you're a maybe, say NO.

6) You are encouraged to change your mind anytime you want.

7) Respect your relationship agreements and communicate with your partner.

8) Get me of my assistant if you have a questions or concern or need assistance with anything during the Cuddle Party.

9) Tears and laughter are both welcome.

10) Respect people's privacy when sharing about Cuddle Parties and do not gossip.

11) Arrive on time.

12) Be hygienically savvy.

Want to know more about Cuddle Party?

Cuddle Party has been around since February 2004.


There is lots of information about Cuddle Parties on the official Cuddle Party website www.cuddleparty.com so if you are curious, be sure to check out the FAQ section and some of the articles too

Be On Time: PLEASE arrive on time at 6:30 PM to check-in and change into your Cuddle Clothes so we can start the Welcome Circle by 7:00 PM.

No Late Arrivals: Sorry - but after the Welcome Circle begins, no late arrivals can enter

What To Wear: Pajamas/Athletic Wear.  Think more comfy than sexy. 

What To Bring: A pillow or stuffed animal if you like. Otherwise, just bring your smiling self.

Your Cuddle Host will provide light snacks and beverages.

Looking forward to Cuddling with you soon,

Registration Details


Cost: $25

Purchase Tickets: https://www.eventbrite.com/e/cuddle-party-for-all-genders-tickets-22465525993

When you register or attend please make a point to mention to us you found this event through NYC Pleasure without Borders MeetUp.

You must get a ticket in advance. This is the only way to ensure space will be reserved for you. Tickets must be purchased in advance - they will not be sold at the door Cost: Men $25 in advance; Women $25 in advance.

Eventbrite requires credit card payments. Sorry no exceptions or walk-ins.

Got Questions? You can post them below.
results.name: Cuddle Party™ For All Genders - Experiential Intimacy Workshop & Social Event

results.description:
Söndörgő (pronounced shoendoergoe) is one of the most active and interesting world music groups in Hungary. The group was founded in 1995 in Szentendre a small Hungarian town near Budapest, with a long-established Serbian tradition. Söndörgő’s style of music is quite different from the traditional, fiddle-led hungarian repertoire. In contrast to most Balkan music, Söndörgő’s playing is not brass band music: they are a tamburitza band. The tambura is a small and agile plucked instrument similar to the mandolin, occasionally supplemented by wind instruments and accordion. Söndörgő’s traditional repertoire is made up of material gathered by Béla Bartók and Tihamér Vujicsics as well as learned from old masters of the tradition.

Söndörgő’s aim is to foster and preserve the Southern Slavic traditions of the Serbs and Croats as found in various settlements in Hungary. Söndörgő’s mission is to research it, arrange it and perform it on stage. The current members of the group are: Áron Eredics, Benjamin Eredics, Dávid Eredics, Salamon Eredics and Attila Buzás.

Discover with them the delicate beauty and fizzing power of a different Balkan sound. Come and dance the čoček, drink a palinka and get dizzy on Söndörgő’s extraordinary rhythms!

Buy Tickets ($20) $12 food minimum or two drink minimum per person.
results.name: Listen to the Söndörgő Ensemble

results.description:
We’re back at it in Brooklyn, with the next phase of our new series at the incredible Kimoto Rooftop, where we’ll be holding it down the way we always do, with three live DJ’s spinning the wildest tracks, as we take in the incredible scenery, from up above. If you hit our initial launch party here 2 months ago, you already know how fun this place gets, so it’s not one to be missed! Plus, there will be some solid drink specials to keep things interesting.

Your 3 DJs will be spinning:
DJ 1 (Green): Top 40 hits, Dance, Pop, etc
DJ 2 (Red): The best of 80’s & 90’s, and 2K music!
DJ 3 (Blue): Hip-Hop, R&B

What the night includes:
Quiet Events Headphones
Glow in the Dark Gear
3 Live DJs battling for your attention
Drink Specials until 11:30 pm:
$6 beer & shot
$7 wines
$8 cocktails

Special Notes:
Dress Code – Smart Casual
-No sportswear, baseball caps or baggy clothing
-Collared shirts and fitted fashionable attire recommended
Tickets are limited, so act fast!
This party is going on rain or shine.
Age Restriction: 21+

HOW IT WORKS
***Bring a credit or debit card for the check-in process*** When you arrive you’ll receive a pair of special wireless headphones. You can adjust the volume and choose between up to three DJ with a flip of a switch. Each headset has a color LED that shows what you are listening to, so you can dance along with those listening to the same DJ as you. It’s super social; just lower the volume or take the headphones off and talk to that girl or guy. There’s no loud music that you have to talk over. Plus, there’s no ringing in your ears when you leave. At the end of the night, be sure to return your headphones as there will be a $100 charge to your credit or debit card if headphones don’t come back.

Kisco, conducted by Marshall Schor, the First Unitarian Society of Westchester, FUSW Coffee Hour Choir of Hastings-on-Hudson, conducted by Richard Slade, and the Community Unitarian Universalist Congregation at White Plains whose CUUC Choir along with Pianist Georgianna Pappas and Director Lisa N. Meyer is hosting the event.

The concert promises an evening of diverse music which begins and concludes with all choirs coming together to perform meaningful and joyful works that will resound with the power that only a large massed choir can provide. For more than 55 years Alvin Ailey has amazed us with their choreography. The Dance Troupe tours everywhere from Detroit Michigan, South Africa and Europe. They have been the source of art for  for well noted audiences. In 2008 Oprah Winfrey along with Sidney Poitier, Cicely Tyson & Ben Vereen celebrated the infamous African American Dance Troupe. If you've never experience Alvin Ailey, this is the moment to do so. Being a member of the organization, I cannot get enough of them. This is the Arts and Performance Event Series. Welcome to the America's magnificent  Alvin Ailey.



This year as a result of our Membership, we are now able to create a group purchase. Members will have first dibs (priority) on group tickets. This will allow us to sit together and get tickets at a EWNYC group price. Group members have requested more of Signature events together as a group.  As promised this will be an ongoing part of the EWNYC Live Performance Speeches and Theater (Broadway and off-Broadway, as well as Jazz Tours)

The New York Social Network (NYSN) has been planning events in and around the city since 2004!  There is something to choose from almost every night and several options each weekend!  It can be hard to figure out which ones may be best for you, especially if you have never been out before.

If you are new to the group or a long time member, this is a fun night to meet others and find out what what we have planned in the coming months. NYSN founder Dave Cervini will be on hand with our staff to welcome all New Members and introduce you to our long time members.  You will enjoy drink specials,  complimentary hot and cold appetizers and lot's of room to socialize network and connect.

This will also be a great opportunity to see what we have in store for 2016.

The World Bar is a nice lounge with lot's of room to sit or wander around while meeting others.

Other Meet Up and Social Networking groups/organizations often invite their members so you also get to network with people from similar groups.

The night will include:

- Complimentary hot and cold appetizers until 9pm

- Drink specials until 9pm

- Music played at conversational levels

Can I come alone? Yes, 95% of those attending tend to come on their own.

What to expect: 60-80 people fairly even split of men and women ages 20's -40's, singles and some couples. Most are there to network and connect.

What to wear: trendy, neat, business casual

How do I get there? take any of the green line trains to 42nd Grand Central or 51st street. Then a short walk towards the East River

How long does it go? We usually start breaking up around 11:30-Midnight

General Admission is $10.00 Please bring exact change to the door.

Once again, this event is being promoted by several Meet Up groups and www.newyorksocialnetwork.com.  There will be tons of people attending.  If you have any questions you can contact the event organizer directly at [masked] or call[masked]

results.description:
Marty Fager will be calling a lively program of contras accompanied by the Gotham Gals!

The Gotham Gals are: 

Julia Hartman on fiddle

Norma Castle, flute and percussion

Robin Russell on piano

Come dance to a live caller and band with Country Dance New York.  We are an intergenerational, multiethnic, smoke and alcohol free, inclusive community with one thing in common:  we love to contra and English country dance! 

Contra dance is a high energy American folk dance accompanied by live string music and taught by a caller.  No partner or experience required.  All dances are taught in advance and the figures are easy to learn.

Please bring a pair of clean, soft soled shoes {no spike heels} to dance in, and a water bottle.  We ask that you not use strongly scented grooming products as the smell can become overwhelming on the dance floor when things start to heat up. 

Country Dance New York has been hosting contra dances most Saturdays, and English country dancing most Tuesdays, at Church of the Village for almost 70 years.   COV is located at 201 W. 13 St., on the northwest corner of 7th Avenue.  

Beginners' session on Saturdays {for contra} is from 7:30 to 8:00.  Dancing for all from 8:00 until 10:45.  Hang out with us at a local diner after the dance.

Beginner's session on Tuesdays {for ECD} is from 7:00 to 7:30.  Dancing for all from 7:30 to 10:30.

Cost:  $15 for general public; $12 members and for full time students with ID.  Be sure to tell the people at the door if this is your first time dancing with us.  They will give you a free pass to return as our guest!

To see what contra dancing looks like, click here:

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=mM5vNzFxxBs 

To see what English country dancing looks like, click here:

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rB40AvJnMUY 

Join us on Facebook:  https://www.facebook.com/groups/2449906414/

For a complete schedule of our upcoming season, and for more information, visit our website.

See you on the dance floor!
results.how_to_find_us: Take the ACE, 1,2,3, L or F train to 14th St. We are on the northwest corner of 13th Street and 7th Avenue. Street address is 201 W. 13th.
results.name: Contra Dance w/ Marty Fager and the Gotham Gals!

results.description:
JOIN US FOR A NIGHT OF HEALING WITH WORLD RENOWNED SOUND HEALER MARK DAVID!!!  

What does a Sound Bath look like?

Most people lie down during a Sound Bath, some choose to sit in a comfortable chair. Eye pillows are often used to help you feel calm and heighten your other senses, especially hearing. the room is often darkened and everything is in place for a peaceful, relaxing time together. Mark usually plays for at least an hour. Most of the instruments are played from one place and occasionally they are brought around the room and sometimes played over your body. The vibrations from the bowls and the gong are especially powerful.

The Sound Bath is a healing session you can experience while resting in a safe and secure place.

A sequence of quartz crystal singing bowls are played, each one keyed to the energy centres (chakras) of the body, where sound nourishes the nervous system.  The results are waves of peace, heightened awareness, and relaxation of the mind, body and spirit.

A Sound Bath can be an unforgettable sound experience for those who seek deep relaxation, rejuvenation and an acceleration of their inward journey. Time is suspended as you enter a world of vibration, sensation and experience. Physical injuries can be healed and old emotional traumas released. Great insights can be accessed. You feel truly, vibrantly alive. Once you’ve had your first Sound Bath you’ll want more.

Sound healing is a powerful healing method that uses vibration tore-tune the body/spirit/mind by balancing the flow of energy through the chakras, bringing about deep relaxation, energizing the physical body and clearing the emotional body. 


With the use of crystal bowls, tuning forks and drums. Mark will renew sense of one’s vitality, clarity, grace and joy can be accessed.

Please bring your own pillows, yoga mat, etc.
results.name: LIVE SOUND BATH HEALING

results.name: Private Member Saturday Night Social (Comp Apps, Drink Specials) Prepay Only

results.description:
Single? New in town? Just looking to get out and meet new people?

Join us for our multi-group member happy hour! ATWYS along with New York Social Network organizes a monthly Saturday night get together for all of our new and existing members.

If you are new to our Meteup group or a long time member, this is a fun night to meet others and find out what what we have planned in the coming months. Event Host, New York Social Network  founder Dave Cervini will be on hand with our staff to welcome all New Members and introduce you to our long time members.  You will enjoy drink specials,  complimentary hot and cold appetizers and lot's of room to socialize network and connect.

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

All ATWYS members who pay in advance for this event will receive a promo code for $7 off a speeddating event as well as $5 off our Dec 12 Mix & Mingle Happy Hour. Please be sure to check your eventbrite order confirmation for the promo codes to use to redeem your discount.

$10 in advance only

Prepay here: http://atwys2013member.eventbrite.com/

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~


The night will include:

-complimentary hot and cold appetizers until 9pm

-Drink specials until 9pm

Can I come alone? Yes, 95% of those attending tend to come on their own.

What to expect: 60-80 people fairly even split of men and women ages 20's -40's, singles and some couples. Most are there to network and connect. 

What to wear: trendy, neat, business casual

How do I get there? take any of the green line trains to 42nd Grand Central or 51st street. Then a short walk towards the East River

How long does it go?  We usually start breaking up around 12:30-1am.

results.description:
ALL AGES
$10 @ The Door = 4 hours of jamming & practice time! 

The Open Jams at Funkadelic Studios are great for musicians who are interested in networking with other like-minded artists, from beginners to professionals in all genres. Attending our open jams allows you to collaborate with musicians, and it's a great way to find potential band members, or to test out and get feedback on new songs that you’re working on!

Since first opening up in 1993, we have become a resource for artists of varying styles and personalities. The atmosphere at Funk, is influenced by our friendly staff and the cool vibe of our city.

Our Open Jams are held every Saturday and its only $10 to attend which gets you four hours of jamming and practice time! So come get something started, network, create and collaborate!
results.how_to_find_us: 5th Floor, on W40th between 7th & 8th ave.
results.name: Music Open Jam @ Funkadelic Studios

group.name: Open Jams NYC at Funkadelic Studios

results.how_to_find_us: www.rainbowmemories.biz
results.name: SPRING FESTIVAL  NEW ORLEANS STYLE!

venue.name: NORTH STREET TAVERN @ The Maple Moor Golf Club

results.description:
ARE YOU READY TO MIX & MINGLE!!

TREAT YOURSELF AND FRIENDS TO AN EXCITING EVENING FILLED WITH COCKTAILS, CONVERSATIONS, DINING, AND DANCING AT THE  NORTH STREET TAVERN.

HAVE A FUN AND EXCITING EVENING WHILE MEETING PEOPLE FROM ALL OVER CT & NY IN THIS WARM AND COMFORTABLE SETTING

12 0THER SINGLE GROUPS WILL BE JOINING US!

THIS IS A MULTI-MEETUP GROUP EVENT.  THE RSVP LIST ON THIS PAGE SHOWS THE ACTUAL ATTENDEES THAT  HAVE R.S.V.P.'d. IN THIS GROUP AND A HEAD COUNT FROM ALL THE OTHERS!

DJ WILL BE PLAYING ALL OF YOUR FAVORITE HITS TO GET YOU ON THE DANCE FLOOR STARTING AT 10 PM.

BRING A FRIEND

BRING SOMEONE YOU KNOW, A FRIEND, A NEIGHBOR, A CO-WORKER, OR GRAB AN EX RELATIONSHIP (ONE WITHOUT A RESTRAINING ORDER) AND GET DOWN TO ONE OF THE BEST SOCIAL MIXERS AROUND!

IF YOU HAVEN'T R.S.V.P.'d YET, PLEASE DO SO NOW TO KEEP AN ACCURATE COUNT!

PLEASE DRESS TO IMPRESS OR CASUALLY NEAT!

PARKING

THERE'S PLENTY OF PARKING AVAILABLE IN IN FRONT OF THE RESTAURANT AND PLEASE USE THE SIDE ENTRANCE BY THE BAR.

COVER CHARGE

THERE WILL BE A $5 COVER CHARGE AT THE DOOR FOR THIS EVENT REGARDLESS WHETHER YOU'RE DINING OR JUST AT THE BAR.

PLEASE PAY AS YOU ARRIVE AND EXACT CHANGE WILL BE APPRECIATED, THANK YOU.

NORTH STREET TAVERN

Welcome to the newly renovated North Street Tavern, right off of exit 25 on the Hutchinson River Parkway.

The North Street Tavern situated on the Maple Moor Golf Course has great food, a large bar, a outdoor patio and dining room, all overlooking the golf course.

The North Street Tavern serves up Westchester Counties finest brick oven pizza and exciting dishes in a unique ambiance. The authentic <a>menu</a> and friendly atmosphere creates a truly enjoyable dining experience for all.

DIRECTIONS

~From CONNECTICUT~

Get on 95 S. to 287 W. (Exit 21) then take the Hutchinson River Parkway S. (Exit 9S), get off at Exit 25 and take a right at the bottom of the ramp, the Golf Course will be on your right.

You can also get on the Merit Parkway which turns into the Hutchinson River Pkwy. and get off exit 25.

From Danbury, take 684 S. to Hutchinson River Pkwy. and get off at Exit 25, at the end of the ramp take a right and the Golf Course will be on the right.

results.description:
Full-Field Soccer - 11 v 11 - Large Goals - Beautiful Turf Field - Friendly but competitive game. 

RSVP's open 6 Days before the Meetup at 8:00pm - 


RSVP's close at 6:00pm the night of the game

Main goal is the have fun, play hard, and have a good time. 

Game Time Officially Starts at 8:15. If you are not on the field ready to play, or are literally changing to play, your spot MAY BE GIVEN AWAY to a member on the wait list if they show up.

(1) we are keeping an 11 v 11 game, with 1 substitute per side; rotating new players in every 10 minutes.

(2) Please only RSVP if you will come. No shows ruin the game for everyone on the field, as well as those who would have come and played in your spot.

(3) Games will be 40-45 minute halves; switching sides at the break. 

• If you are on the wait list and come to the field, and a no show occurs, by 8:15 you will be given their spot.

Fee is $4.00 for the night - Payment will be taken at Half-Time. Please have cash available to pay. If you do not have cash, please go to the ATM prior the game. All players will receive a 1-time exception.
results.how_to_find_us: Park is right off of Kent Ave + N 10th St. - (L) Bedford Ave, or (G) Nassau Ave
